editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE WONDER: A Woman keeps a SECRET. A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the Theatre Royal in Drury-Lane. By Her MAJESTY's Servants.
Written by the AUTHOR of the GAMESTER.
LONDON: Printed for E. CURLL, at the Dial and Bible, againſt St. Dunſtan's Church in Fleet-ſtreet, and A. BETTESWORTH at the Red Lyon, on London-Bridge. 1714.

div.head: TO His Serene HIGHNESS George Auguſtus, Electoral Prince of HANOVER, Duke and Marqueſs of Cambridge, Earl of Milford-Haven, Viſcount North-Allerton, Baron of Tewksbury, and Knight of the moſt Noble Order of the Garter.
div.p:
THIS Dedication, which I always intended to Addreſs to your HIGHNESS, and which
I was in hopes might have Congratulated you upon your being in England, muſt now wait for your Arrival. I am ſure I ſpeak the Senſe of every honeſt Briton, when I ſay that we expect it with the utmoſt Impatience.

Your Highneſs, who has been hitherto a Stranger among us, cannot eaſily conceive the Confidence we repoſe in you; and it will, perhaps, hardly be believ'd in future Ages, that the firſt Report of the Duke
of Cambridge's Deſign to Viſit us, ſhould raiſe the PUBLICK CREDIT of the Britiſh Nation.
We are fill'd with Pleaſure, to think that the moſt accompliſh'd of Princes will perfect himſelf in the Arts of Government under the Eye, and Direction of the Greateſt of Queens.

If it is poſſible there ſhou'd be a Sett of Men among us who can wiſh to ſee their Country become a Province of France, it is, I think, pretty evident that
your Reſidence in Great-Britain will ſoon put an End to ſuch Impious Expectations.

The Law of Nature makes it not improbable that you will one Day reign over us, and what may not our Poſterity expect from a Prince who in his early Years diſtinguiſh'd himſelf in the Cauſe of Liberty, and led their Anceſtors on to Victory? The Balance of Europe will doubtleſs be kept ſteady by that Hand which has already perform'd
ſuch Wonders in order to maintain it; our Religion, our Laws, and Civil Rites can be in no Danger under a Prince, who from his Converſation with our Nobility, and his Preſence at their moſt important Debates, will have a perfect Inſight into all the Parts of our Conſtitution.

Britain ſhall from hence-forward claim your HIGHNESS intirely as her own, and endeavour by the moſt convincing Proofs of her Love and Reſpect, to make you
forget the Court of your Illuſtrious Father.

The Pains you have already taken to acquire our Tongue, cannot fail to endear you to every Engliſhman; yet as the Idioms of a Language are the laſt Things we arrive at, I am in hopes an Engliſh Comedy will not be thought the moſt improper Preſent that could be offer'd to your HIGHNESS.

There is no doubt but you will ſoon be made the Subject of more Correct Pens, and receive a juſt Tribute
from the greateſt Authors of our Nation: In the mean Time, tho' I am, perhaps, the moſt unworthy, I have at leaſt one Advantage, that I am the firſt who have ſhewn my Reſpect in this Manner, and ſued for your Protection.

closer.signed: I am your HIGHNESS's Moſt Obedient, Moſt Devoted, Moſt Humble Servant SUSANNA CENT LIVRE.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: I Don't pretend to write a Preface, either to point out the Beauties, or to excuſe the Errors, a judicious Reader may poſſibly diſcover in the following Scenes, but to give thoſe excellent Comedians their Due, to whom, in ſome Meaſure the beſt Dramatick Writers are oblig'd. The Poet and the Player are like Soul and Body, indiſpenſibly neceſſary to one another; the correct Author makes the Player ſhine, whilſt the judicious Player makes the Poet's Fame immortal. I freely acknowledge my ſelf oblig'd to the Actors in general, and to Mr. Wilks, and Mrs. Oldfield in particular; and I owe them this Juſtice to ſay, That their inimitable Action cou'd only ſupport a Play at ſuch a Seaſon, and among ſo many Benefits. Let this encourage our Engliſh Bards to Write, furniſh but the artful Player with Materials, and his Skill will lay the Foundation for your Fame.

I muſt again repeat that which I meet with every where, I mean the juſt Admiration of the Performance of Mr. Wilks, and Mrs. Oldfield, and own that they much out-did in Action the ſtrongeſt of my Conceptions; for tho' Nature was my Aim in the laſt Act of this Comedy, yet Nature herſelf were ſhe to paint a Love Quarrel, wou'd only Copy them.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: OUR Author fears the Criticks of the Stage,
Who like Barbarians, ſpare nor Sex, nor Age;
She trembles at thoſe Cenſors in the Pit,
Who think good Nature ſhows a want of Wit:
Such Malice, Oh, what Muſe can undergo it?
To ſave themſelves, they always Damn the Poet.
Our Author flies from ſuch a Partial Jury,
As wary Lovers from the Nymphs of Drury:
To the few Candid Judges for a Smile,
She humbly ſues to Recompence her Toil.
To the bright Circle of the Fair, ſhe next,
Commits her Cauſe, with Anxious Doubts perplext.
Where can ſhe with ſuch hopes of Favour kneel,
As to thoſe Judges, who her Frailties feel?
A few Miſtakes, her Sex may well excuſe,
And ſuch a Plea, No Woman ſhou'd refuſe:
If ſhe ſucceeds, a Woman gains Applauſe,
What Female but muſt favour ſuch a Cauſe.
Her Faults,—If ſuch there be:—Then,—paſs 'em by,
And only on her Beauties fix your Eye.
In Plays, like Veſſels floating on the Sea,
There's none ſo Wiſe to know their Deſtiny.
In this, howe'er the Pilot's Skill appears,
While by the Stars his conſtant Courſe he ſteers;
In this our Author does her Judgment ſhew,
That for her Safety ſhe relies on You.
Your Approbation Fair ones, can't but move,
Thoſe ſtubborn Hearts, which firſt you taught to Love:
The Men muſt all Applaud this Play of ours,
For who dares See with other Eyes, than Yours?

list.head: Men.

Don Felix, his Son, in Love with Violante.
Frederick, A Merchant.
Don Pedro, Father to Violante.
Colonel Britton, A Scotchman.
Gibby, His Footman.
Liſſardo, Servant to Felix.

list.head: Women.

Donna Iſabella, Siſter to Felix.
Flora, Her Maid.
Inis, Maid to Violante.

body.head: THE WONDER: A Woman keeps a SECRET.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: FREDERICK.
sp.p: MY Lord Don Lopez.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: How do you Frederick?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: At your Lordſhip's Service, I am glad to ſee you look ſo well my Lord, I hope Antonio is out of danger.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Quite contrary, his Feaver increaſes they tell me, and the Surgeons are of Opinion his wound is mortal.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your Son Don Felix is ſafe I hope.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I hope ſo too, but they offer large Rewards to apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: When heard your Lordſhip from him?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Not ſince he went, I forbad him writing till the publick News gave him an Account of Antonio's Health, Letters might be intercepted, and the place of his Abode diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your Caution was good my Lord; tho' I am impatient to hear from Felix, yet his Safety is my chief Concern. Fortune has maliciouſly ſtruck a Bar between us in the Affairs of Life, but ſhe has done me the Honour to unite our Souls.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I am not ignorant of the friendſhip between my Son and You, I have heard him commend your Morals and lament your want of noble Birth.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That's Nature's fault my Lord, 'tis ſome comfort not to owe ones Misfortunes to ones Self, yet 'tis impoſſible not to regret the want of noble Birth.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: 'Tis pity indeed ſuch excellent Parts as you are Maſter of, ſhould be eclipſed by mean Extraction.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Such Commendation wou'd make me vain my Lord, did you not caſt in the allay of my Extraction.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: There is no Condition of Life without its Cares, and it is the Perfection of a Man to wear 'em as eaſie as he can; this unfortunate Duel of my Son's does not paſs without Impreſſion. But ſince 'tis paſt Prevention, all my Concern is now, how he may eſcape the Puniſhment; if Antonio dies, Felix ſhall for England. You have been there, what ſort of People are the Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My Lord, the Engliſh are by Nature, what the ancient Romans were by Diſcipline, couragious, bold, hardy, and in love with Liberty. Liberty is the Idol of the Engliſh, under whoſe Banner all the Nation Liſts, give but the Word for Liberty, and ſtraight more armed Legions wou'd appear, than France, and Philip keep in conſtant Pay.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I like their Principles; who does not wiſh for Freedom in all Degrees of Life? Tho' common Prudence ſometimes makes us act againſt it, as I am now obliged to do, for I intend to marry my Daughter to Don Guzman, whom I expect from Holland every Day, whither he went to take Poſſeſſion of a large Eſtate left him by his Uncle.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You will not ſure Sacrifice the lovely Iſabella to Age, Avarice, and a Fool, pardon the Expreſſion my Lord, but my Concern for your beauteous Daughter tranſports me beyond that good Manners which I ought to pay your Lordſhip's preſence.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: I can't deny the juſtneſs of the Character Frederick; but you are not inſenſible what I have ſuffered by theſe Wars, and he has two things which render him very agreeable to me for a Son-in-Law, he is Rich and well Born; as for his being a Fool, I don't conceive how that can be any Blot in a Husband, who is already poſſeſs'd of a good Eſtate.—A Poor Fool indeed is a very Scandalous thing, and ſo are your Poor Wits, in my Opinion, who have nothing to be vain of, but the inſide of their Sculls; now for Don Guzman I know I can rule him, as I think fit; this is acting the Politick part, Frederick, without which, it is impoſſible to keep up the Port of this Life.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But have you no Conſideration for your Daughter's welfare my Lord?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Is a Husband of twenty thouſand Crowns a Year, no Conſideration? Now I think it a very good Conſideration.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: One way, my Lord. But what will the World ſay of ſuch a Match?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Sir, I value not the World a Button.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I cannot think your Daughter can have any Inclination for ſuch a Husband.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p:
There I believe you are pretty much in the right, tho' it is a Secret, which I never had the Curioſity
to enquire into, nor I believe ever ſhall—Inclination quotha! Parents would have a fine time on't, if they conſulted their Childrens Inclinations! I'll venture you a Wager, that in all the Garriſon Towns in Spain and Portugal, during the late War, there were not three Women, who have not had an Inclination to every Officer in the whole Army; does it therefore follow, that their Fathers ought to Pimp for them? No, no, Sir, it is not a Father's buſineſs to follow his Childrens Inclinations till he makes himſelf a Beggar.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But this is of another Nature my Lord.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Look ye Sir, I reſolve ſhe ſhall Marry Don Guzman the Moment he arrives; tho' I cou'd not govern my Son, I will my Daughter, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This Match my Lord, is more prepoſterous than that which you propoſed to your Son, from whence aroſe this fatal—Quarrel, Don Antonio's Siſter Elvira, wanted Beauty only, but Guzman every thing, but—

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Money—and that will purchaſe every thing, and ſo Adieu.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Monſtrous! Theſe are the Reſolutions which deſtroy the comforts of Matrimony—he is Rich, and well born, powerful Arguments indeed! Could I but add them to the Friendſhip of Don Felix, what might I not hope? But a Merchant and a Grandee of Spain, are inconſiſtent Names—Liſſardo! From whence come you?

div.stage: Enter Liſſardo in a Riding Habit.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: That Letter will inform you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I hope your Maſter's ſafe.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: I left him ſo, I have another to deliver which requires—haſte—Your moſt humble Servant Sir (bowing.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: To Violante, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Reads) Dear Frederick, the two chief Bleſſings of this Life are a Friend, and a Miſtreſs; to be debarred the ſight of thoſe is not to live. I hear nothing of Antonio's Death, therefore reſolve to venture to thy Houſe this Evening, impatient to ſee Violante, and embrace my Friend. Yours Felix.
Pray Heaven he comes undiſcover'd—ha! Colonel Britton!

div.stage: (Enter Colonel Britton in a Riding Habit.)

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Frederick, I rejoice to ſee thee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What brought you to Lisbon Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: La Fortune de la Guerre, as the French ſay, I have commanded theſe Three laſt Years in Spain, but my Country has thought fit to ſtrike up a Peace, and give us good Proteſtants leave to hope for Chriſtian Burial, ſo I reſolve to take Lisbon in my way home.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If you are not provided of a Lodging Colonel, pray command my Houſe, while you ſtay.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If I were ſure I ſhould not be troubleſome, I wou'd accept your offer, Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So far from trouble Colonel, I ſhall take it as a particular Favour, what have we here?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My Footman, this is our Country Dreſs you muſt know, which for the Honour of Scotland, I make all my Servants wear.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: What mun I de with the Horſes, an like yer Honour, they will tack cold gin, they ſtand in the Cauſsway.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh! I'll take Care of them, what hoa Vaſquez.
put thoſe Horſes which that honeſt Fellow will ſhow you into my Stable, do you hear? And feed them well.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.p: Yes Sir.—Sir, by my Maſter's Order, I am Sir, your moſt obſequious humble Servant. Be pleas'd to lead the Way. (bowing.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: S'bled gang yer gat Sir, and I fall follow yee: Iſe tee hungry to feed on Compliments.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha, ha, a comical Fellow.—Well, how do you like our Country, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why Faith Frederick, a Man might paſs his Time agreeably enough with Inſide of a Nunnery; but to behold ſuch Troops of ſoft, plump, tender melting, wiſhing, nay willing Girls too, thro' a damn'd Grate, gives us Brittons ſtrong Temptation to Plunder. Ah Frederick, your Prieſts are wicked Rogues. They immure Beauty for their own proper Uſe, and ſhow it only to the Laity to create Deſires, and inflame Accompts, that they may purchaſe Pardons at a dearer Rate.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I own Wenching is ſomething more difficult here than in England, where Womens Liberties are ſubſervient to their Inclinations, and Husbands ſeem of no Effect but to take Care of the Children which their Wives provide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And does Reſtraint get the better of Inclination with your Women here? No, I'll be ſworn not even in fourſcore. Don't I know the Conſtitution of the Spaniſh Ladies?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And of all Ladies where you come, Colonel, you were ever a Man of Gallantry.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ah Frederick, the Kirk half ſtarves us Scotchmen. We are kept ſo ſharp at home, that we feed like Cannibals abroad. Hark ye, haſt thou never a pretty Acquaintance now, that thou wouldſt conſign over to a Friend for half an Hour, ha?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Faith Colonel, I am the worſt Pimp in Chriſtendom, you had better truſt to your own Luck, the Women will ſoon find you out I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Ay, but it is dangerous forraging in an Enemy's Country, and ſince I have ſome hopes of ſeeing
my own again, I had rather purchaſe my Pleaſure, than run the hazard of a Stilletto in my Guts. 'Egad, I think I muſt e'en Marry and Sacrifice my Body for the good of my Soul, wilt thou recommend me to a Wife then, one that is willing to exchange her Moyders for Engliſh Liberty; ha Friend,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: She muſt be very handſome I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Col:
sp.p: The handſomer the better—but be ſure ſhe has a Noſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ay, ay, and ſome Gold.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh, very much Gold, I ſhall never be able to ſwallow the Matrimonial Pill, if it be not well Gilded.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Puh, Beauty will make it ſlide down nimbly.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: At firſt perhaps it may, but the Second or Third Doſe will choak me—I confeſs Frederick, Women are the prettieſt Play-things in Nature, but Gold, ſubſtantial Gold, gives 'em the Air, the Mien, the Shape, the Grace, and Beauty of a Goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And has not Gold the ſame Divinity in their Eyes Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Too often.—Money is the very God of Marriage, the Poets dreſs him in a Saffron Robe, by which they Figure out the golden Deity, and his lighted Torch blazons thoſe mighty Charms, which encourage us to Liſt under his Banner.

l.hi: None marry now for Love, no, that's a Jeſt,
The ſelf ſame Bargain, ſerves for Wife, and Beaſt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You are always gay Colonel, come ſhall we take a refreſhing Glaſs at my Houſe, and conſider what has been ſaid.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have two or three Compliments to diſcharge for ſome Friends, and then I ſhall wait on you with Pleaſure: Where do you live?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: At yon Corner Houſe with the green Rails.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: In the cloſe of the Evening I will endeavour to kiſs your Hand. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I ſhall expect you with impatience.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: For goodneſs ſake, Madam, where are you going in this Pet?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Any where to avoid Matrimony; the thoughts of a Husband is as terrible to me as the ſight of a Hobgoblin.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Ay, of an old Husband, but if you might chuſe for your ſelf, I fancy Matrimony wou'd be no ſuch frightful Thing to you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You are pretty much in the right, Inis; but to be forc'd into the Arms of an Ideot, a ſneaking, ſnivling, drivling, avaricious Fool, who has neither Perſon to pleaſe the Eye, Senſe to charm the Ear, nor generoſity to ſupply thoſe Defects, ah Inis! What pleaſant Lives Women lead in England, where Duty wears no Fetter but Inclination: The Cuſtom of our Country inſlaves us from our very Cradles, firſt to our Parents, next to our Husbands; and when Heaven is ſo kind to rid us of both theſe, our Brothers ſtill uſurp Authority, and expect a blind Obedience from us, ſo that Maids, Wives, or Widows, we are little better than Slaves to the Tyrant Man, therefore to avoid their Power, I reſolve to caſt my ſelf into a Monaſtery.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: That is, you'll cut your own Throat to avoid another's doing it for you. Ah Madam, thoſe Eyes tell me you have no Nuns fleſh about you; a Monaſtery quotha! Where you'll wiſh your ſelf in the Green-Sickneſs in a Month.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What care I, there will be no Man to plague me.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p:
No, nor what's much worſe, to pleaſe you
neither—Ad'slife Madam, you are the Firſt Woman that e'er diſpair'd in a Chriſtian Country—Were I in your Place—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Why what wou'd your Wiſdom do if you were?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: I'de imbark with the firſt fair Wind with all my Jewels, and ſeek my Fortune on t'other ſide the Water; no Shoar can treat you worſe than your own; there's ne'er a Father in Chriſtendom ſhould make me marry any Man againſt my Will.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I am too great a Coward to follow your Advice. I muſt contrive ſome way to avoid Don Guzman, and yet ſtay in my own Country.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Muſt you ſo Miſtreſs, but I ſhall take Care to prevent you. (Aſide.) Iſabella, whether are you going my Child?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Ha! my Father! To Church, Sir.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: The old Rogue has certainly over-heard her. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Your Devotion muſt needs be very ſtrong, or your Memory very weak; my Dear, why, Veſpers are over for this Night; come, come, you ſhall have a better Errand to Church than to ſay your Prayers there. Don Guzman is arriv'd in the River, and I expect him aſhore to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Ha, to Morrow!

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: He writes me Word, That his Eſtate in Holland is worth 12000 Crowns a Year, which, together with what he had before, will make thee the happieſt Wife in Lisbon.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: And the moſt unhappy Woman in the World. Oh Sir! If I have any Power in your Heart, if the tenderneſs of a Father be not quite extinct, hear me with Patience.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: No Objections againſt the Marriage, and I will hear whatever thou haſt to ſay.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: That's torturing me on the Rack, and forbidding me to Groan; upon my Knees I claim the Priviledge of Fleſh and Blood.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: I grant it, thou ſhalt have an Arm full of Fleſh and Blood to Morrow; Fleſh and Blood quotha, Heaven forbid I ſhould deny thee Fleſh and Blood, my Girl.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Here's an old Dog for you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Do not miſtake, Sir, the fatal Stroak which ſeparates Soul and Body, is not more terrible to the Thoughts of Sinners, than the Name of Guzman to my Ears.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Puh, puh; you Lye, you Lye.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: My frighted Heart beats hard againſt my Breaſt, as if it ſought a Paſſage to your Feet, to beg you'd change your Purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: A very pretty Speech this, if it were turn'd into blank Verſe, it would ſerve for a Tragedy; why, thou haſt more Wit than I thought thou hadſt, Child.——I fancy this was all extempore, I don't believe thou did'ſt ever think of one Word on't before.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Yes, but ſhe has, my Lord, for I have heard her ſay the ſame Things a thouſand Times.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: How, how, What do you top your ſecond Hand Jeſts upon your Father, Huſſy, who knows betther what's good for you than you do your ſelf; remember 'tis your Duty to Obey.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: (Riſing) I never diſobey'd before, and wiſh I had not Reaſon now; but Nature has got the better of my Duty, and makes me loath the harſh Commands you lay.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Ha, ha, very fine! Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Death it ſelf wou'd be more welcome.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I am your Daughter, my Lord, and can boaſt as ſtrong a Reſolution as your ſelf; I'll die before I'll marry Guzman.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Say you ſo, I'll try that preſently. (Draws.) Here let me ſee with what Dexterity you can breath a Vein now, (offers her his Sword.) The Point is pretty ſharp, 'twill do your Buſineſs I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir, What do you mean to put a Sword into the Hands of a deſperate Woman?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Deſperate, ha, ha, ha, you ſee how deſperate ſhe is, what art thou frighted little Bell. ha!

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I confeſs I am ſtartled at your Morals, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Child, thou hadſt better take the Man, he'll hurt thee the leaſt of the two.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I ſhall take neither, Sir, Death has many Doors, and when I can live no longer with Pleaſure, I ſhall find one to let him in at without your aid.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou ſo, my dear Bell. Ods, I'm afraid thou art a little Lunatick Bell. I muſt take Care of thee, Child, (takes hold of her, and pulls out of his Pocket a Key.) I ſhall make bold to ſecure thee, my Dear: I'll ſee if Locks and Bars can keep thee till Guzman comes; go, get you into your Chamber.

l.hi: There I'll your boaſted Reſolution try,
And ſee who'll get the better, you or I.

sp.stage: (puſhes her in, and locks the Door.

head.hi: SCENE, a Room in Don Pedro's Houſe.

div.stage: Enter Donna Violante reading a Letter, and Flora following.

sp.speaker: Flora
sp.p: WHAT muſt that Letter be read again?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Yes, and again, and again, and again, a thouſand Times again, a Letter from a faithful Lover can ne'er be read too often; it ſpeaks ſuch kind, ſuch ſoft, ſuch tender Things—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: But always the ſame Language.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: It does not charm the leſs for that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: In my Opinion nothing charms that does not change; and any Compoſition of the four and Twenty Letters, after the firſt Eſſay, from the ſame Hand, muſt be dull, except a Bank Note, or a Bill of Exchange.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Thy Taſte is my Averſion— (Reads.) My all that's charming, ſince Life's not Life exil'd from thee this Night ſhall bring me to thy Arms. Frederick and thee are all I truſt: Theſe ſix Weeks abſence has been in Love's Accompt ſix Hundred Years; when it is Dark expect the wonted Signal at thy Window, till when adieu, thine more than his own. Felix.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Who wou'd not have ſaid as much to a Lady of her Beauty, and twenty Thouſand Pounds.—Were I a Man, methinks I cou'd have ſaid a Hundred finer Things, I wou'd have compar'd your Eyes to the Stars, your Teeth to Ivory, your Lips to Corral, your Neck to Allabaſter, your Shape to—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
No more of your Bombaſt, Truth is the beſt Eloquence in a Lover.—What Proof remains ungiven of his Love? When his Father threatned to diſinherit him, for refuſing Don Antonio's Siſter, from whence
ſprung this unhappy Quarrel; did it ſhake his Love for me? And now, tho' ſtrict Enquiry runs thro' every Place, with large Rewards to apprehend him, does he not venture all for me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: But you know, Madam, your Father Don Pedro deſigns you for a Nun, and ſays your Grand-Father left you your Fortune upon that Condition.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Not without my Approbation, Girl, when I come to one and Twenty, as I am inform'd. But however, I ſhall run the risk of that; go call in Liſſardo.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, now for a thouſand Verbal Queſtions.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Well, and how do you do Liſſardo?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Ah, very weary, Madam—Faith thou look'ſt wondrous Pretty Flora. (Aſide to Flora.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How came you?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: En Cavalier, Madam, upon a Hackney-Jade, which they told me formerly belong'd to an Engliſh Colonel. But I ſhould rather have thought ſhe had been bred a good Roman Catholick all her Life time; for ſhe down of her Knees to every Stock, and Stone, we came along by. My Chaps Waters for a Kiſs, they do, Flora. (Aſide to Flora.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You'd make one believe you are wondrous fond now.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Where did you leave your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Od, if I had you alone Houſe-Wife, I'd ſhow you how fond I cou'd be— (Aſide to Flora) at a little Farm-Houſe, Madam, about five Miles off; he'll be at Don Frederick's in the Evening—Od, I will ſo revenge my ſelf of thoſe Lips of thine. (to Flora.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Is he in Health?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh, you counterfeit wondrous well. (to Liſſardo.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: No, every Body knows I Counterfeit very ill. (to Flora.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How ſay you! Is Felix ill, What's his Diſtemper? Ha!

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: A pies on't, I hate to be interrupted—Love, Madam, Love—In ſhort, Madam, I believe he has thought of nothing but your Ladyſhip ever ſince he left Lisbon. I am ſure he cou'd not, if I may Judge of his Heart by my own (Looking lovingly upon Flora.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How came you ſo well acquainted with your Maſter's Thoughts, Liſſardo?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: By an infallible Rule, Madam; Words are the Pictures of the Mind, you know; now to prove he thinks of nothing but you, he talks of nothing but you—for Example, Madam, coming from Shooting t'other Day, with a brace of Partridges, Liſſardo ſaid he, go bid the Cook roaſt me theſe Violantes—I flew into the Kitchin, full of Thoughts of thee, cry'd, here Cook, roaſt me theſe Florellas. (to Flora.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, excellent—You mimick your Maſter then it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: I can do every thing as well as my Maſter, you little—Rogue, another time: Madam, the Prieſt came to make him a Viſit, he call'd out haſtily, Liſſardo ſaid he, bring a Violante for my Father to ſit down on;—then he often miſtook my Name, Madam, and call'd me Violante; in ſhort, I heard it ſo often, that it became as familiar to me as my Prayers.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You liv'd very Merrily then it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Oh, exceeding Merry Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ha! Exceeding Merry; had you Treats and Balls?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Oh! Yes, yes, Madam, ſeveral.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You are Mad, Liſſardo, you don't mind what my Lady ſays to you. (Aſide to Liſſardo.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ha! Balls—Is he ſo Merry in my abſence? And did your Maſter Dance, Liſſardo?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Dance Madam! Where Madam?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why, at thoſe Balls you ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Balls! What Balls Madam?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why, ſure you are in Love, Liſſardo; did not you ſay, but now, you had Balls where you have been?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Balls, Madam! Odſlife, I ask your Pardon Madam! I, I, I, had miſlaid ſome Waſh-Balls of my Maſter's t'other Day; and becauſe I cou'd not think where I had laid them, juſt when he ask'd for them, he very fairly broke my Head, Madam, and now it ſeems I can think of nothing elſe. Alas! He Dance Madam! No, no, poor Gentleman, he is as Melancholy as an unbrac'd Drum.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Poor Felix! There, wear that Ring for your Maſter's Sake, and let him know, I ſhall be ready to receive him,

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: I ſhall Madam— (puts on the Ring) methinks a Diamond-Ring is a vaſt addition to the little Finger of a Gentleman. (admiring his Hand.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That Ring muſt be mine—Well Liſſardo! What haſte you make to pay off Arrears now? Look how the Fellow ſtands?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Egad, methinks I have a very pretty Hand—and very white—and the Shape!—Faith, I never minded it ſo much before!—In my Opinion it is a very fine ſhap'd Hand—and becomes a Diamond Ring, as well as the firſt Grandees in Portugal.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The Man's tranſported! Is this your Love! This your Impatience!

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: (Takes Snuff.) Now in my Mind—I take Snuff with a very Fantee Air—Well, I am perſuaded I want nothing but a Coach, and a Title, to make me a very fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Liſſardo, (Curtecying) if I may preſume to ſpeak to you, without affronting your little Finger.—

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Odſo Madam, I ask your Pardon—Is it to me, or to the Ring—you direct your Diſcourſe, Madam.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Madam! Good lack! How much a Diamond Ring improves one.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Why, tho' I ſay it—I can carry my ſelf as well as any Body—But what wer't thou going to ſay Child?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Why I was going to ſay, that I fancy you had beſt let me keep that Ring, it will be a very pretty Wedding Ring, Liſſardo, would it not?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Humph! Ah! But—but—but—I believe I ſhan't marry yet a while.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You ſhan't, you ſay—Very well! I ſuppoſe you deſign that Ring for Inis.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: No, no, I never bribe an old Acquaintance—Perhaps I might let it ſparkle in the Eyes of a Stranger a little, till we came to a right Underſtanding—But then like all other Mortal Things, it would return from whence it came.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Inſolent—Is that your Manner of dealing.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: With all but thee—Kiſs me you little Rogue you. (hugging her.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Little Rogue! Prithy Fellow, don't be ſo familiar, (puſhing him away,) if I mayn't keep your Ring, I can keep my Kiſſes,

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: You can, you ſay! Spoke with the Air of a Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Reply'd with the Spirit of a ſerving Man.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Prithy Flora, don't let you and I fall out, I am in a merry Humour, and ſhall certainly fall in ſomewhere.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: What care I, where you fall in.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why do you keep Liſſardo ſo long, Flora? When you don't know how ſoon my Father may awake, his Afternoon Naps are never long.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Had Don Felix been with her, ſhe wou'd not have thought the Time long; theſe Ladies conſider no body's Wants but there own. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Go, go, let him out, and bring a Candle.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: I fly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: The Day draws in, and Night,——the Lover's Friend advances—Night more welcome than the Sun to me, becauſe it brings my Love.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Shrieks within.) Ah! Thieves, Thieves! Murder, Murder!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Shrieks.) Ah! Defend me Heaven! What do I hear? Felix is certainly purſu'd, and will be taken.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How, now! Why doſt ſtare ſo? Anſwer me quickly! What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Oh Madan! As I was letting out Liſſardo, a Gentleman ruſhed between him and I, ſtruck down my Candle, and is bringing a dead Perſon in his Arms into our Houſe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ha! A dead Perſon! Heaven grant it do's not prove my Felix.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Here they are Madam.

div.stage: Enter Colonel with Iſabella in his Arms.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I'll retire till you diſcover the Meaning of the Accident.

p.stage: (Sets Iſabella down in a Chair, and addreſſes himſelf to Flora.)

sp.speaker: Madam,
sp.p: The Neceſſity this Lady was under, of being convey'd into ſome Houſe with Speed and Secrecy, will I hope excuſe any Indecency I might be guilty of, in preſſing ſo rudely into this—I am an entire Stranger to her Name and Circumſtances; wou'd I were ſo to her Beauty too (Aſide) I commit her Madam to your Care, and fly to make her Retreat ſecure; if the Street be clear, permit me to return and learn from her own Mouth. If I can be farther ſerviceable, pray Madam, how is the Lady of this Houſe call'd?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Violante, Senior—He is a handſome Cavalier and promiſes well. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Are you ſhe Madam?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Only her Woman, Senior.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your humble Servant. Mrs. Pray be careful of the Lady— (gives her two Moyders.)

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Two Moyders! Well he is a generous Fellow this is the only Way to make one careful; I find all Countries underſtand the Conſtitution of a Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Was you diſtracted Flora? To tell my Name to a Man you never ſaw! Unthinking Wench! Who knows what this may turn to—What is the Lady dead! Ah! Defend me Heaven, 'tis Iſabella, Siſter to my Felix, what has be • a •… n her? Pray Heaven he's ſafe,—Run and fetch ſome cold Water, (Exit Flora, and enters with Water) Iſabella, Friend, ſpeak to me, Oh! Speak to me, or I ſhall die with Apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: See, ſhe revives.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh! Hold my deareſt Father, do not force me, indeed I cannot love him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How wild ſhe talks—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Ha! Where am I?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: With one as ſenſible of thy Pain as thou thy ſelf canſt be.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Violante! What kind Star preſerv'd, and lodg'd me here?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: It was a Terreſtial Star, call'd a Man, Madam; pray Jupiter he proves a lucky one.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh! I remember now, forgive me dear Violante, my Thoughts ran ſo much upon the Danger I eſcap'd, I had forgot.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: May I not know your Story?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Thou art no Stranger to one part of it; I have often told thee that my Father deſign'd to ſacrifice me to the Arms of Don Guzman, who it ſeems is juſt return'd from Holland, and expected aſhore to-morrow, the Day that he has ſet to celebrate our Nuptials, upon my refuſing to obey him, he lock'd me into my Chamber, vowing to keep me there till he arriv'd, and force me to conſent. I know my Father to be poſſitive, never to be won from his Deſign; and having no hope left me, to eſcape the Marriage, I leap'd from the Window, into the Street.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You have not hurt your ſelf I hope.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: No, a Gentleman paſſing by, by Accident caught me in his Arms; at firſt my Fright made me apprehend it was my Father, till he aſſur'd me to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: He is a very fine Gentleman I promiſe you, Madam, and a well bred Man I warrant him. I think I never ſaw a Grandee put his Hand into his Pocket with a better Air in my whole Life Time; then he open'd his Purſe with ſuch a Grace, that nothing but his Manner of preſenting me the Gold cou'd equal.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: There is but one common Road to the Heart of a Servant, and 'tis impoſſible for a generous Perſon to miſtake it.—But how came you hither Iſabella?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I know not, I deſir'd the Stranger to convey me to the next Monaſtery, but e'er I reach'd thy Door, I ſaw, or fancy'd that I ſaw, Liſſardo, my Brother's Man, and the Thought that his Maſter might not be far off, flung me into a Swoon, which is all that I remember: Ha! What's here (takes up a Letter) For Collonel Britton, to be left at the Poſt-Houſe in Lisbon; this muſt be drop'd by the Stranger which brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Thou art fal'n into the Hands of a Soldier, take care he does not lay thee under Contribution, Girl.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I find he is a Gentleman; and if he be but unmarried I cou'd be content to follow him all the World over.—But I ſhall never ſee him more I fear. (Sighs, and Pauſes.)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What makes you ſigh Iſabella?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: The fear of falling into my Father's Clutches again.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Can I be ſerviceable to you?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Yes if you'l conceal me two or three Days.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You command my Houſe and Secrecy.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I thank you Violante,—I wiſh you wou'd oblige me with Mrs. Flora a while.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I'll ſend for her to you—I muſt watch if Dad be ſtill aſleep, or here will be no room for Felix.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Well I don't know what ails me, but methinks I wiſh I cou'd find this Stranger out.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Does your Ladyſhip want me Madam?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Ay, Mrs. Flora, I reſolve to make you my Confident.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I ſhall endeavour to diſcharge my Duty, Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I doubt it not, and deſire you to accept this as a Token of my Gratitude.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Oh dear Senjora, I ſhou'd have been your humble Servant, without a Fee.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I believe it—But to the Purpoſe—Do you think if you ſaw the Gentleman which brought me hither you ſhou'd know him again?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: From a Thouſand Madam, I have an excellent Memory where a handſome Man's concern'd; when he went away he ſaid he would return again immediately, I admire he comes not.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Here, did you ſay? You rejoyce me—Tho' I'll not ſee him, if he comes, cou'd not you contrive to give him a Letter?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: With the Air of a Duanna.—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Not in this Houſe—You muſt veil and follow him—He muſt not know it comes from me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: What do you take me for a Novice in Love Affairs? 'Tho I have not practic'd the Art ſince I have been in Donna Violantes Service, yet I have not loſt the Theory of a Chamber-Maid—Do you write the Letter, and leave the reſt to me—Here, here, here's Pen Ink and Paper.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I'll do't in a Minute.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: So! This is Buſineſs after my own Heart; Love always takes care to reward his Labourers, and Great Britain ſeems to be his Favourite Country.—Oh, I long to ſee the t'other two Moyders with a Britiſh Air—Methinks there's a Grace peculiar to that Nation in making a Preſent.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: So I have done, now if he does but find this Houſe again!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: If he ſhou'd not—I warrant I'll find him if he's in Liſbon.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Flora, watch my Papa; he's faſt aſleep in his Study—If you find him ſtir, give me Notice.—Hark, I hear Felix at the Window, admit him inſtantly, and then to your Poſt.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What ſay you Violante? Is my Brother come?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: It is his Signal at the Window.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: (Kneels.) Oh! Violante, I conjure thee by all the love thou bear'ſt to Felix—By thy own generous Nature—Nay more, by that unſpotted Vertue thou art Miſtreſs of, do not diſcover to my Brother I am here.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Contrary to your Deſire, be aſſur'd I never ſhall, but where's the Danger?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
Art thou born in Lisbon, and ask that Queſtion? He'll think his Honour blemiſh'd by my Diſobedience,
and wou'd reſtore me to my Father, or kill me, therefore dear, dear, Girl.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Depend upon my Friendſhip, nothing ſhall draw thy Secret from theſe Lips, not even Felix, tho' at the Hazard of his love; I hear him coming, retire into that Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Remember Violante, upon thy Promiſe my very Life depends.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: When I betray thee, may I ſhare thy Fate.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My Felix, My everlaſting Love.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My Life, my Soul! My Violante!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What Hazards doſt thou run for me; Oh, how ſhall I requite thee?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: If during this tedious painful Exile, thy Thoughts have never wander'd from thy Felix, thou haſt made me more than Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Can there be room within this Heart for any but thy ſelf. No, if the God of Love were loſt to all the reſt of Human Kind, thy Image wou'd ſecure him in my Breaſt, I am all Truth, all Love, all Faith, and know no jealous Fears.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My Heart's the proper Sphere where Love reſides; cou'd he quit that he wou'd be no where found: And yet Violante I'm in doubt.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Did I ever give thee Cauſe to doubt my Felix.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: True love has many Fears, and Fear as many Eyes as Fame; yet ſure I think they ſee no Fault in thee—What's that?(the Colonel pats at the Window. without.)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What? I heard nothing.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Ha! What means this Signal at your Window?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Some Body perhaps, in paſſing by; might accidentally hit it, it can be nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (Within) Hiſt, hiſt, Donna Violante, Donna Violante.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: They uſe your Name by Accident too, do they Madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: There is a Gentleman at the Window, Madam, which I fancy to be him who brought Iſabella hither; ſhall I admit him!(Aſide to Violante.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Admit Diſtraction rather, thou art the Cauſe of this, unthinking Wretch!(Aſide to Flora.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What has Miſtreſs Scout brought you freſh Intelligence? Death, I'll know the Bottom of this immediately!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Scout, I ſcorn your Words, Senior.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, nay, you muſt not leave me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Oh! 'Tis not fair, not to Anſwer the Gentleman, Madam, It is none of his Fault, that his Viſit proves unſeaſonable; pray let me go, my Preſence is but a reſtraint upon you. (ſtruggles to get from her)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Was ever Accident ſo Miſchievous?(Aſide.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: It muſt be the Colonel, now to deliver my Letter to him.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Hark, he grows impatient at your delay—Why do you hold the Man, whoſe Abſence wou'd oblige you, pray let me go, Madam; conſider, the Gentleman wants you at the Window. Confuſion!(ſtruggles ſtill.)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: It is not me he wants.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Death, not you? Is there another of your Name in the Houſe? But, come on, convince me of the Truth of what you ſay: Open the Window, if his Buſineſs does not lye with you, your Converſation may be heard—This, and only this, can take of my Suſpicion—What do you pauſe! Oh Guilt! Guilt! Have I caught you, Nay then I'll leap the Balcony, If I remember, this Way leads to it. (breaks from her and goes to the Door where Iſabella is.)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Oh Heavens! What ſhall I do now, hold, hold,
hold, hold, not for the World—You enter there—Which way ſhall I preſerve his Siſter from his Knowledge?(Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What have I touch'd you; do you fear your Lover's Life?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I fear for none but you—For goodneſs Sake, do not ſpeak ſo loud my Felix. If my Father hear you I am loſt for ever, that Door opens into his Apartment, What ſhall I do if he enters? There he finds his Siſter—If he goes out he'll quarrel with the Stranger—Nay do not ſtruggle to be gone my Felix—If I open the Window he may diſcover the whole Intrigue, and yet of all Evils we ought to chuſe the leaſt. Your Curioſity ſhall be ſatisfied. Whoe'er you are that with ſuch Inſolence dare uſe my Name, and give the Neighbourhood Pretence to reflect upon my Conduct. I charge you inſtantly be gone, or expect the Treatment you deſerve.
sp.stage: (goes to the Window and throws up the Saſh.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ask your Pardon Madam, and will obey; but when I left this Houſe to Night.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Good!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: It is moſt certainly the Stranger, what will be the Event of this Heaven knows. (Aſide) you are miſtaken in the Houſe I ſuppoſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: No, no, he is not miſtaken—Pray Madam let the Gentleman go on.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Wretched Misfortune, pray be gone Sir, I know of no Buſineſs you have here.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I wiſh I did not know it neither—But this Houſe contains my Soul, then can you blame my Body for hovering about it!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Diſtraction! He will infallibly diſcover Iſabella. I tell you again you are miſtaken; however for your own Satisfaction call To-Morrow.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p:
Matchleſs Impudence! An Aſſignation before
my Face—No he ſhall not live to meet your wiſhes.
sp.stage: (Takes out a Piſtol and goes towards the Window; ſhe catches hold of him.)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ah! (Shrieks) hold I conjure you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: To-morrow's an Age Madam! May I not be admitted to Night?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: If you be a Gentleman I command your Abſence. Unfortunate! What will my Stars do with me?(Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have done—Only this—Be careful of my Life, for it is in your keeping.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Pray obſerve the Gentleman's Requeſt Madam. (Walking off from her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I am all Confuſion. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You are all Truth, all Love, all Faith; Oh thou all Woman!—How have I been deceiv'd? S'Death, cou'd not you have impos'd upon me for this one Night? Cou'd neither my faithful Love, nor the Hazard I have run to ſee you, make me worthy to be cheated on?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Can I bear this from you?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (Repeats) When I left this Houſe to Night—to Night the Devil! Return ſo ſoon!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh Iſabella! What haſt thou involv'd me in?(Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (Repeats) This Houſe contains my Soul.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Yet I reſolve to keep the Secret. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (Repeats) Be careful of my Life, for 'tis in your keeping.—Damnation!—How ugly ſhe appears?(Looking at her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Do not look ſo ſternly on me, but believe me Felix, I have not injur'd you, nor am I falſe.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Not falſe, not injur'd me! Oh Violante, loſt and abandon'd to thy Vice! Not falſe, Oh monſtrous!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Indeed I am not—There is a Cauſe which I muſt not reveal—Oh think how far Honour can oblige your Sex—Then allow a Woman may be bound by the ſame Rule to keep a Secret.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Honour, what haſt thou to do with Honour, thou that canſt admit plurality of Lovers, a Secret? Ha, ha, ha, his Affairs are wondrous ſafe, who truſts his Secret to a Womans keeping, but you need give your ſelf no Trouble about clearing this Point Madam, for you are become ſo indifferent to me, that your Truth, and Falſhood are the ſame!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My Love!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My Torment!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: So I have deliver'd my Letter to the Colonel, and receiv'd my Fee. (Aſide) Madam, your Father bad me ſee what Noiſe that was—For Goodneſs ſake Sir, why do you ſpeak ſo loud!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I underſtand my cue Miſtreſs, my Abſence is Neceſſary, I'll oblige you. (going)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh let me undeceive you firſt!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: 'Tis very poſſible if I durſt.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Durſt! Ha, ha, ha, durſt quotha.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But another time I'll tell thee all.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Nay, now or never.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Now it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Then it ſhall never be—Thou moſt ungrateful of thy Sex, farewel.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh exquiſite Tryal of my Friendſhip! Yet not even this, ſhall draw the Secret from me,

l.hi: That I'll preſerve, let Fortune frown, or ſmile,
And truſt to Love, my Love to reconcile.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: WAS ever Man thus plagu'd! Odſheart, I cou'd ſwallow my Dagger for Madneſs; I know not what to think, ſure Frederick had no Hand in her Eſcape—She muſt get out of the Window; and ſhe could not do that without a Ladder; and who cou'd bring it her, but him? Ay, it muſt be ſo. The diſlike he ſhew'd to Don Guzman in our Diſcourſe to Day, confirms my Suſpicion, and I will charge him home with it; ſure Children were given me for a Curſe! Why, what innumerable Misfortunes attend us Parents, when we have employ'd our whole Care to educate, and bring our Children up to Years of Maturity? Juſt when we expect to reap the Fruits of our Labour; a Man ſhall in the tinkling of a Bell, ſee one hang'd, and t'other whor'd—This Graceleſs Baggage—But I'll to Frederick immediately, I'll take the Alguzil with me, and ſearch his Houſe; and if I find her, I'll uſe her—by St. Anthony, I don't know how I'll uſe her.

head.hi: The Scene changes to the Street.

div.stage: Enter Colonel with Iſabella's Letter in his Hand, and Gibby following.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Well, tho' I cou'd not ſee my fair Incognita, Fortune, to make me amends, has flung another Intrigue in my way. Oh! How I love theſe pretty, kind, coming Females, that won't give a Man the trouble of wracking his Invention to deceive them.—Oh, Portugal! Thou dear Garden of Pleaſure—Where Love drops down his Mellow Fruit, and every Bough bends to our Hands, and ſeems to cry come, Pull and Eat, how deliciouſly a Man lives here without ſear of
the Stool of Repentance?—This Letter I receiv'd from a Lady in a Vail—Some Duanna! Some neceſſary Implement of Cupid; I ſuppoſe the Stile is frank and eaſie, I hope like her that writ it. (Reads) "Sir, I have ſeen your Perſon, and like it—Very Conciſe.—And if you'll meet at five a Clock in the Morning upon the Terriero de paſſa, half an Hours Converſation will let me into your Mind.—" Ha, ha, ha, a Philoſophical Wench: This is the firſt time I ever knew a Woman had any Buſineſs with the Mind of a Man.—"If your Intellects anſwer your outward Appearance, the Adventure may not diſpleaſe you. I expect you'll not attempt to ſee my Face, nor offer any thing unbecoming the Gentleman I take you for:—"Humph, the Gentleman ſhe takes me for, I hope ſhe takes me to be Fleſh and Blood, and then I am ſure I ſhall do nothing unbecoming a Gentleman. Well, if I muſt not ſee her Face, it ſhall go hard if I don't know where ſhe lives.—Gibby,

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Here, an like yer Honour.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Follow me at a good Diſtance, do you hear Gibby?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: In troth dee I, weel eneugh, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am to meet a Lady upon the Terriero de paſſa.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: The Deel an min Eyn gin I keen her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But you will when we come there, Sirrah

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Like eneugh, Sir, I have as ſharp an Eyn tul a Bony Laſs, as ere a Lad in aw Scotland, an what mun I dee wi her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, if ſhe and I part, you muſt watch her Home, and bring me Word where ſhe lives.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: In troth ſal I Sir, gin the Deel tak her not.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come along then, 'tis pretty near the time.—I like a Woman that riſes early to perſue her Inclination.

l.hi: Thus we improve the Pleaſures of the Day,
Whilſt taſteleſs Mortals ſleep their Time away.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Your Lady run away, and you not know whether! Say you?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: She never greatly car'd for me after finding you and I together; but you are very Grave, methinks, Liſſardo.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: (Looking upon the Ring) Not at all—I have ſome Thoughts indeed of altering my Courſe of living; there is a critical Minute in every Man's Life, which if he can but lay hold of, he may make his Fortune.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Ha! What, do I ſee a Diamond-Ring! Where the duce had he that Ring? You have got a very pretty Ring there, Liſſardo.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Ay, the Trifle is pretty enough.—But the Lady which gave it me is a Bona Roba in Beauty, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: I can't bear this—The Lady! What Lady pray?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Oh fy! There's a Queſtion to ask a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: A Gentleman! Why, the Fellow's ſpoil'd; is this your Love for me? Ungrateful Man, you'll break my Heart, ſo you will.

sp.speaker: Liſſ
sp.p: Poor tender hearted Fool.—

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: If I knew who gave you that Ring, I'd tear her Eyes out, ſo I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: So, now the Jade wants a little Coaxing; why, what doſt thou weep for now, my Dear? Ha!

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe Flora gave you that Ring; but I'll—

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: No, the Devil take me if ſhe did, you make me Swear now—So, they are All for the Ring, but I ſhall bob 'em: I did but Joke, the Ring is none of mine, it is my Maſters; I am to give it to be new Set, that's all, therefore prithy dry thy Eyes, and kiſs me come.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: And do you really ſpeak Truth now?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Why, Do you doubt it?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: So, ſo, very well! I thought, there was an Intrigue between him and Inis, for all he has forſworn it ſo often. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Nor han't you ſeen Flora ſince you came to Town.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Ha! How dares ſhe Name my Name?(Aſide.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: No, by this Kiſs I han't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Here's a diſſembling Varlet. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Nor don't you love her at all?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Love the Devil, why did not I always tell thee ſhe was my Averſion.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Did you ſo, Villain!
sp.stage: (Strikes him a box on the Ear.)

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Zounds ſhe here! I have made a fine ſpot of Work on't. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: What's that for? Ha.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I ſhall tell you by and by, Mrs Frippery, if you don't get about your Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Who do you call Frippery, Mrs. Trolup? Pray get about your Buſineſs: if you go to that, I hope you pretend to no Right and Title here.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: What the Devil do they take me for, an Acre of Land, that they quarrel about Right and Title to me?(Aſide.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pray, what right have you, Miſtreſs, to ask that Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: No matter for that, I can ſhow a better Title to him than you, I believe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What, has he given thee Nine Months earneſt for a living Title? Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Don't fling your flearing Jeſts at me, Mrs. Boldface, for I won't take 'em, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: So! Now am I as great as the fam'd Alexander. But my dear Statira and Roxana, don't exert your ſelves ſo much about me: Now, I fancy, if you wou'd agree lovingly together, I might in a modeſt way ſatisfie both your Demands upon me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You ſatisfie! No, Sirrah, I am not to be ſatisfy'd ſo ſoon as you think, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: No, nor I neither.—What do you make no difference between us?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You pitiful Fellow you; what you fancy, I warrant, that I gave my ſelf the trouble of dogging you, out of love to your filthy Perſon, but you are miſtaken, Sirrah—It was to detect your Treachery.—How often have you Sworn to me that you hated Inis, and only carried fair for the good Chear ſhe gave you; but that you could never like a Woman with crooked Legs, you ſaid.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: How, how, Sirrah, crooked Legs! Ods, I cou'd find in my Heart.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Here's a Lying young Jade now! Prithy, my Dear, moderate thy Paſſion. (Coaxingly.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: I'd have you to know, Sirrah, my Legs was never—your Maſter, I hope, underſtands Legs better than you do, Sirrah. (paſſionately.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: My Maſter, ſo ſo. (Shaking his Head and winking.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I am glad I have done ſome Miſchief, however. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: (To Inis.) Art thou really ſo fooliſh to mind what an enrag'd Woman ſays! Do'nt you ſee ſhe does it on Purpoſe to part you and I, (runs to Flora) cou'd not you find the Joke without putting your Self in a Paſſion! You ſilly Girl you; why, I ſaw you follow us plain enough, Mun, and ſaid all this, that you might not go back with only your Labour for your Pains—But you are a revengeful young Slut tho'. I tell you that, but come Kiſs, and Friends.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Don't thing to Coax me, hang your Kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Odſheart, here's my Maſter, the Devil take both theſe Jades, for me, what ſhall I do with them?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Ha! 'Tis Don Felix's Voice; I wou'd not have him find me here, with his Foot-Man, for the World.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (Within) Why, Liſſardo, Liſſardo!

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Coming Sir, What a Pox will you do?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Bleſs me, which way ſhall I get out!

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Nay, nay, you muſt e'en ſet your Quarrel aſide, and be content to be mew'd up in this Cloaths Preſs together, or ſtay where you are, and Face it out—There is no help for it!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Put me any where, rather than that; come, come, let me in.
sp.stage: (He opens the Preſs, and ſhe goes in.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: I'll ſee her hang'd, before I'll go into the Place where ſhe is.—I'll truſt Fortune with my deliverance: Here us'd to be a pair of back Stairs, I'll try to find them out.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Was you aſleep, Sirrah, that you did not hear me call?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: I did hear you, and anſwer'd you, I was coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Go get the Horſes ready, I'll leave Lisbon to Night, never to ſee it more.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Hey day! What's the Matter now?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Pray tell me, Don Felix! What has ruffled your Temper thus?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: A Woman—Oh Friend, who can name Woman, and forget Inconſtancy!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This from a Perſon of mean Education were excuſable, ſuch low Suſpicions have their ſource from vulgar Converſation; Men of your politer Taſte never raſhly Cenſure.—Come, this is ſome groundleſs Jealouſie.—Love raiſes many Fears.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p:
No, My Ears convey'd the Truth into my Heart, and Reaſon juſtifies my Anger: Violante's falſe
and I have nothing left, but thee, in Lisbon, which can make me wiſh ever to ſee it more, except Revenge upon my Rival, of whom I am ignorant. Oh, That ſome Miracle wou'd reveal him to me, that I might thro' his Heart puniſh my Infidelity.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, here's your Father Don Lopez coming up.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Do's he know that I am here?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: I can't tell, Sir, he ask'd for Don Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Did he ſee you?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: I believe not, Sir; for as ſoon as I ſaw him, I ran back to give my Maſter Notice.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Keep out of his Sight then.—And dear Frederick, permit me to retire into the next Room, for I know the Old Gentleman will be very much diſpleaſed at my return without his leave.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Quick, quick, begon, he is here.

div.stage: Enter Don Lopez, ſpeaking as he Enters.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Mr. Alguzil, wait you without till I call for you. Frederick, an Affair brings me here—which—requires Privacy.—So that if you have any Body within Ear ſhot, pray order them to retire.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: We are private, my Lord, ſpeak freely.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, I muſt tell you, that you had better have pitch'd upon any Man in Portugal to have injur'd, than my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (Peeping.) What means my Father?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I underſtand you not, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Tho', I am Old, I have a Son.—Alaſs! Why Name I him? He knows not the Diſhonour of my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I am confounded! The diſhonour of his Houſe▪

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Explain your ſelf my Lord! I am not conſcious of any diſhonourable Action, to any Man much leſs to your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe! you have debauch'd my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Debauch'd my Siſter! Impoſſible! He cou'd not, durſt not be that Villain.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſcorn ſo foul a Charge.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: You have debauch'd her Duty at leaſt, therefore inſtantly reſtore her to me, or by St. Anthony I'll make you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Reſtore her my Lord! Where ſhall I find her?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: I have thoſe that will ſwear ſhe is here in your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Ha! In this Houſe?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You are miſinform'd my Lord, upon my Reputation I have not ſeen Donna Iſabella, ſince the Abſence of Don Felix.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Then pray Sir—If I am not too inquiſitive, What Motive had you for thoſe Objections you made againſt her Marriage with Don Guzman Yeſterday?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The Diſagreeableneſs of ſuch a Match, I fear'd, wou'd give your Daughter cauſe to curſe her Duty, if ſhe comply'd with your Demands, that was all my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: And ſo you help'd her thro' the Window to make her diſobey.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Ha, my Siſter gone! Oh Scandal to our Blood!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This is inſulting me my Lord, when I aſſure you I have neither ſeen, nor know any thing of your Daughter—If ſhe is gone, the Contrivance was her own, and you may thank your Rigour for it.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, however my Rigour ſhall make bold to ſearch your Houſe, here call in the Alguzile—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: (Peeping) The Alguzile! What in the Name of Wonder will become of me!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The Alguzile! My Lord you'l repent this.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: No Sir, 'tis you that will repent it, I charge you in the King's Name to aſſiſt me in finding of my Daughter—Beſure you leave no Part of the Houſe unſearch'd; come, follow me.
sp.stage: (Goes towards the Door where Felix is; Frederick draws, and plants himſelf before the Door.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt firſt know by what Authority you pretend to Search my Houſe, before you enter here.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: How! Sir, dare you preſume to draw your Sword, upon the Repreſentative of Majeſty! I am Sir, I am his Majeſty's Alguzile, and the very Quinteſſence of Authority—therefore put up your Sword, or I ſhall order you to be knock'd down—for know Sir, the Breath of an Alguzile, is as dangerous, as the Breath of a Demy-Culverin.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: She is certainly in that Room, by his Guarding the Door—if he Diſputes your Authority, knock him down I ſay.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I ſhall ſhow you ſome Sport firſt; the Woman you look for is not here, but there is ſomething in this Room, which I'll preſerve from your ſight at the Hazard of my Life.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Enter I ſay, nothing but my Daughter can be there—force his Sword from him.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Villains ſtand off! Aſſaſſinate a Man in his own Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, Miſericordia, what do I ſee my Son!

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p:
Ha, his Son! Here's five hundred Pounds good, my Brethren, if Antonio dies, and that's in the Surgeons Power, and he's in love with my Daughter you know—Don Felix! I command you to ſurrender your ſelf into the Hands of Juſtice, in order, to raiſe
me and my Poſterity, and in Conſideration you loſe your Head to gain me five hundred Pounds, I'll have your Generoſity recorded on your Tomb-Stone—at my own proper Coſt, and Charge—I hate to be ungrate-ful.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Here's a generous Dog now—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Oh that ever I was born—Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Did I not tell you, you wou'd repent my Lord, What ho! Within there (Enter Servants) arm your ſelves, and let not a Man in, or out, but Felix—Look ye Alguzile when you wou'd betray my Friend for filthy Lucre, I ſhall no more regard you as an Officer of Juſtice, but as a Thief and Robber thus reſiſt you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Gen'rous Frederick! Come on Sir, we'll ſhow you Play for the five hundred Pounds.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Fall on, ſeize the Money right or wrong ye Rogues.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Alguzile! I'll give you the five hundred Pound, that is, my Bond to pay it upon Antonio's Death, and twenty Piſtoles however things go, for you and theſe honeſt Fellows to drink my Health.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Say you ſo my Lord! Why look ye my Lord, I bear the young Gentleman no ill Will my Lord If I get but the five hundred Pounds, my Lord—why look ye my Lord—'Tis the ſame thing to me whether your Son be hanged or not my Lord,

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Scoundrels.—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Ay, well, thou art a good natur'd Fellow that is the Truth on't—Come then we'll to the Tavern, and ſign and ſeal this Minute, Oh Felix be careful of thy ſelf, or thou wilt break my Heart;

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Now Frederick, tho' I ought to thank you for your Care of me, yet till I am ſatisfied about my Father's Accuſation, I can't return the Acknowledgments I owe you: Know you aught relating to my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I hope my Faith, and Truth, are known to you—And here by both I ſwear, I am ignorant of every Thing relating to your Father's Charge.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Enough, I do believe thee! Oh Fortune! Where will thy Malice end!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, I bring you joyful News, I am told that Don Antonio is out of Danger and now in the Palace.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I wiſh it be true, then I'm at Liberty to watch my Rival, and perſue my Siſter; prithy Frederick, inform thy ſelf of the Truth of this Report.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I will this Minute—Do you hear, let no body in to Don Felix till my return.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I'll obſerve Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: (Peeping) They have almoſt frighted me out of my Wits—I'm ſure—Now Felix is alone, I have a good Mind to pretend I came with a Meſſage from my Lady; but then how ſhall I ſay I came into the Cupboard. (Aſide.

div.stage: Enter Servant, ſeeming to oppoſe the Entrance of ſome body.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I tell you Madam Don Felix is not here.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: (Within) I tell you Sir he is here, and I will ſee him. (breaks in) You are as difficult of Acceſs Sir, as a firſt Miniſter of State.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Stars! My Lady here!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: If your Viſit was deſign'd to Frederick, Madam, he is abroad,

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No Sir, the Viſit is to you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You are very punctual in your Ceremonies Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Tho' I did not come to return your Viſit, but to take that which your Civility ought to have brought me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: If my Ears, my Eyes and my Underſtanding ly'd, then I am in your Debt, elſe not Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I will not charge them with a Term ſo groſs, to ſay they ly'd, but call it a Miſtake, nay call it any thing to excuſe my Felix—Cou'd I, Think ye, cou'd I put off my Pride ſo far, poorly to diſſemble a Paſſion which I did not feel? Or ſeek a Reconciliation, with what I did not love? Do but conſider, If I had entertain'd another, ſhou'd I not rather embrace this Quarrel, pleas'd with the Occaſion that rid me of your Viſits and gave me Freedom to enjoy the Choice which you think I have made; have I any Intereſt in thee but my Love? Or am I bound by aught but Inclination to ſubmit and follow thee—No Law whilſt ſingle binds us to obey, but you by Nature, and Education, are oblig'd to pay a Deference to all Woman kind.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Theſe are fruitleſs Arguments: 'Tis moſt certain thou wert dearer to theſe Eyes then all that Heaven e'er gave to Charm the Senſe of Man, but I wou'd rather tear them out, than ſuffer 'em to delude my Reaſon, and enſlave my Peace.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Can you love without Eſteem? And where is the Eſteem for her you ſtill ſuſpect? Oh Felix! There is a Delicacy—in Love, which equals even a religious Faith; true Love ne'er doubts the Object it adores, and Scepticks there, will disbelieve their Sight.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Your Notions are too refin'd for mine Madam. How now, what do you want?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Only my Maſter's Cloak out of this Preſs Sir, that's all, Oh! The Devil,—The Devil,
sp.stage: (Opens the Preſs, ſees Flora, and roars out.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ha, a Woman conceal'd! Very well Felix!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Diſcover'd! Nay then Legs befriend me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: A Woman in the Preſs!
How the Devil came a Woman there, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay now?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Now Liſſardo ſhew your Wit to brin gyour Maſter off.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Off Madam! Nay, nay, nay, there, there needs no great Wit to, to, to, to bring him off Madam, for ſhe did, and ſhe did not come as, as, as, as a, a a Man may ſay directly to, to, to, to ſpeak with my Maſter Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I ſee by your Stammering, Liſſardo, that your Invention is at at a very low Ebb.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: S'Death Raſcal, ſpeak without Heſſitation, and the Truth too, or I ſhall ſtick my Stilletto in your Guts.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No, no, your Maſter miſtakes, he wou'd not have you ſpeak the Truth.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Madam my Sincerity wants no excuſe.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: I am ſo confounded between one and the other, that I can't think of a Lye— (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Sirrah fetch me this Woman back inſtantly, I'll know what Buſineſs ſhe had here!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Not a Step; your Maſter ſhan't be put to the Bluſh—Come a Truce Felix! Do you ask me no more Queſtions about the Window, and I'll forgive this.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I ſcorn Forgiveneſs where I own no Crime, but your Soul conſcious of its Guilt, wou'd fain lay hold of this Occaſion to blend your Treaſon with my Innocence.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Inſolent! Nay, if inſtead of owning your Fault you endeavour to inſult my Patience, I muſt tell you Sir, you don't behave your ſelf like that Man of Honour you wou'd be taken for, you ground your Quarrel with me upon your own Inconſtancy; 'tis plain you are falſe your ſelf, and wou'd make me the Agreſſor—It was not for nothing the Fellow oppos'd my Entrance—This laſt Uſage has given me back my
Liberty, and now my Father's Will ſhall be obey'd without the leaſt Reluctance.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Oh, ſtubborn, ſtubborn Heart, what wilt thou do? Her Father's Will ſhall be obey'd! Ha, That carries her to a Cloyſter, And cuts of all my Hopes at once—By Heaven ſhe ſhall not, muſt not leave me. No ſhe is not falſe, at leaſt my Love now repreſents her true, becauſe I fear to loſe her, Ha! Villain, art thou here! (turns upon Liſſardo) tell me this Moment who this Woman was, and for what Intent ſhe was here conceal'd—Or▪

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Ah, good Sir forgive me, and I'll tell you the whole Truth.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Out with it then—

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: It, it it, was Mrs. Flora Sir. Donna Violante's Woman—you muſt know Sir, we have had a ſneaking Kindneſs for one another a great while—She was not willing you ſhould know it, ſo when ſhe heard your Voice, ſhe ran into the Cloaths Preſs, I wou'd have told you this at firſt, but I was afraid of her Lady's knowing it, this is the Truth as I hope for a whole Skin, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: If it be not, I'll not leave you a whole Bone in it Sirrah—fly, and obſerve if Violante goes directly home.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Yes Sir, yes.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I muſt convince her of my Faith, Oh! How irreſolute is a Lovers Heart! My Reſentments cool'd when hers grew high—Nor can I ſtruggle longer with my Fate, I cannot quit her, no I cannot, ſo abſolute a Conqueſt has ſhe gain'd—Woman's the greateſt ſovereign Power on Earth.

l.hi: In vain Men ſtrive their Tyranny to quit,
Their Eyes command, and force us to ſubmit.
So have I ſeen a metled Courſer fly,
Tear up the Ground, And toſs his Rider high;
Till ſome experienc'd Maſter found the Way,
With Spur and Rein to make his Pride obey.

div.stage: Enter Colonel, and Iſabella vail'd. Gibby at a Diſtance.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then you ſay, it is impoſſible for me to wait of you home Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I ſay it is inconſiſtent with my Circumſtance Colonel, and that Way impoſſible for me to admit of it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Conſent to go with me then—I lodge at one Don Fredericks's a Merchant juſt by here, he is a very honeſt Fellow and I dare confide in his Secrecy.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Ha, does he lodge there? Pray Heaven I am not diſcover'd. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What ſay you my Charmer? Shall we breakfaſt together; I have ſome of the beſt Bohea in the Univerſe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: puh! Bohea! Is that the beſt Treat you can give a Lady at your Lodgings—Colonel!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well hinted—No, no, no, I have other Things at thy Service Child.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What are thoſe Things pray?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My Heart, Soul, and Body into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Has the laſt no Incumbrance upon it, can you make a clear Title, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: all Free-hold Child, and I'll afford the a very good Bargain.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Au my Sol, they mak muckle Wards about it, Iſe ſeer weary with ſtanding, Iſe e'en tak a Sleep.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: If I take a Leaſe, it muſt be for Life, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt have me as long, or as little Time as thou wilt; my Dear, come lets to my Lodging, and we'll Sign and Seal this Minute.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh, not ſo faſt, Colonel, there are many Things to be adjuſted before the Lawyer and the Parſon comes.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The Lawyer, and the Parſon! No, no, ye little Rogue, we can finiſh our Affairs without the help of the Law—or the Goſpel.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Indeed but we can't, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Indeed! Why haſt thou then trappan'd me out of my warm Bed this Morning for nothing! Why, this is ſhowing a Man half famiſh'd, a well furniſh'd Larder, then clapping a Padlock on the Door, till you Starve him quite.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: If you can find in your Heart to ſay Grace, Colonel, you ſhall keep the Key.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I love to ſee my Meat before I give Thanks, Madam, therefore uncover thy Face, Child, and I'll tell thee more of my Mind.—If I like you—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I dare not risk my Reputation upon your Ifs, Colonel—and ſo Adieu. (Going.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, we muſt not part.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: As you ever hope to ſee me more, ſuſpend your Curioſity now; one Step farther looſes me for ever.—Show your ſelf a Man of Honour, and you ſhall find me a Woman of Honour.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, for once, I'll truſt to a Blind Bargain, Madam.— (Kiſſes her Hand, and parts.) But I ſhall be too Cunning for your Ladyſhip, if Gibby obſerves my Orders: Methinks theſe Intrigues, which relate to the Mind, are very inſipid.—The Converſation of Bodys is much more diverting.—Ha! What do I ſee, my Raſcal aſleep? Sirrah, did I not charge you to watch the Lady? And is it thus you obſerve my Orders, ye Dog.
sp.stage: (Kicks him all this while, and he ſhrugs, and rubs his Eyes, and Yawns.)

sp.speaker: Gib.
