sp.p: That's Treu, an lik your Honour; but I thought that when ence ye had her in yer awn Honds, yee mite a orderd her yer ſal weal eneugh without me, an ye keen, an like yer Honour.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sirrah, hold your impertinent Tongue, and make haſte after her; if you don't bring me ſome Account of her, never dare to ſee my Face again.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Ay! This is bony Wark indeed to run three hunred Mile to this wicked Town, an before I can weel fill my Wem, to be ſent a Whore hunting after this black ſhee Devil.—What Gat ſal I gang to ſpeer for this Wutch now? Ah, for a ruling Elder—or the Kirks Treaſerer—or his Mon.—Id gar, my Maſter mak twa oh this;—But I'm ſeer there's na ſike honeſt People here, or there wou'd na be ſo muckle Sculdudrie.Fornication.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Geud Mon, did yee ſee a Woman, a Lady ony gate here away enow?

sp.speaker: Eng. Man.
sp.p: Yes, a great Many. What kind of a Woman is it you inquire after.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Geud troth, ſhe's ne Kenſpekle, ſhe's aw in a Clowd.—

sp.speaker: Eng. Man.
sp.p: What, it's ſome High-land Monſter which you brought over with you I ſuppoſe, I ſee no ſuch not I, kenſpekle quotha!

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Huly, huly, Mon, the Deel pike out yer Eyn, and then you'll ſee the barer, yee Engliſh bag Pudin Tike.

sp.speaker: Eng. Man.
sp.p: What ſays the Fellow?(Turning to Gibby.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Say! I ſay I am a better Fellow than e'er ſtude upon yer Shanks—an gin I heer meer a yer din, deal a my Sol, Sir, but Iſe crack your Crown.

sp.speaker: Eng. Man.
sp.p: Get you gone you Scotch Raſcal, and thank your Heathen Dialect, which I don't underſtand, that you han't your Bones broke.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Ay! An ye do no underſtond a Scots Man's Tongue—Iſe ſe gin yee can underſtond a Scots Man's Gripe: Wha's the bater Man now Sir?
sp.stage: (Lays hold of him, ſtrikes up his Heels, and gets a Stride over him.)

div.stage: Here Violante croſſes the Stage, Gibby jumps up from the Man, and bruſhes up to Violante.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: I vow, Madam, but I am glad that yee, and I are foregather'd.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What wou'd the Fellow have?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Nothing, away Madam, wo worth yer Heart, what a muckle deel a Miſchief had yee like to bring upon poor Gibby.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: The Man's Drunk.—

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: In troth am I not.—An gin I had not fond ye, Madam, the Laird knows when I ſhou'd; for my Maſter bad me nere gang Heam, without Tydings of yee, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Sirrah, get about your Buſineſs, or I'll have your Bones drub'd.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Geud Faith, my Maſter has e'en dun that te yer Honds, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Who is your Maſter? Friend.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Mony e'en Spiers the gat, they ken right weel.—It is no ſo long ſen yee parted wi him, I wiſh he kent yee haafe as weel as yee ken him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Pugh, the Creature's mad, or miſtakes me for ſome Body elſe; and I ſhou'd be as Mad as he, to talk to him any longer.

div.stage: Enter Liſſardo at the upper end of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: So, ſhe's gone Home I ſee. What did that Scotch Fellao want with her? I'll try to find it out, perhaps I may diſcover ſomething that may make my Maſter Friends with me again.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p:
Are ye gaune, Madam, a Deel ſcope in yer Company, for I'm as weeſe as I was; but I'll bide and ſee whaſe Houſe it is, gin I can meet wi ony Civel Body to Spier at.—Weel of aw Men in the Warld, I think our Scots Men the greateſt Feuls, to leave their weel favour'd honeſt Women at Heam, to rin walloping
after a pack of Gyrcarlings here, that ſhame to ſhow their Faces, and peer Men, like me, are forc'd to be their Pimps; a Pimp! Godſwarbit, Gibby's ne'er be a Pimp.—An yet in troth it is a threving Trade; I rememmer a Country-Man aw mi ean, that by ganging a ſike like Errands as I am now, come to grat Preferment: My Lad, Wot yee wha lives here?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: An did yee ſe a Lady gang in but now?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: An dee yee ken her te?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: It was Donna Violante his Daughter; what the Devil makes him ſo inquiſitive? Here is ſomething in it, that's certain: 'Tis a cold Morning Brother, what think you of a Dram?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: In troth, very weel Sir.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: You ſeem an honeſt Fellow, prithy lets Drink to our better Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Wi aw my Heart, Sir, gang yer gate to the next Houſe, and Iſe follow ye.—

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Come along then.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Don Pedro de Mendoſa.—Donna Violante his Daughter, that's as right as my Leg now.—Iſe need na meer, I'll tak a Drink an then to my Maſter.—

l.hi: Iſe bring him News will mak his Heart full Blee,
Gin he rewards it not, Deel Pimp for me.

div.stage: Enter Iſabella in a gay Temper, and Violante out of Humour.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: MY Dear, I have been ſeeking you this half Hour, to tell you the moſt lucky Adventure.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And you have pitch'd upon the moſt unlucky Hour for it, that you cou'd poſſibly have found in the whole four and Twenty.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Hang unlucky Hours, I won't think of them; I hope all my Misfortunes are paſt.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And mine all to come.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I have ſeen the Man I like.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And I have ſeen the Man that I cou'd wiſh to hate.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: And you muſt aſſiſt me in diſcovering whether he can like me, or not.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You have aſſiſted me in ſuch a Diſcovery already, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What ſay you my Dear?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I ſay I am very unlucky at Diſcoveries Iſabella; I have too lately made one pernicious to my Eaſe, your Brother is falſe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Moſt true.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Some Villain has traduc'd him to you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No, Iſabella, I love too well to truſt the Eyes of others; I never Credit the ill judging World, or form Suſpicions upon vulgar Cenſures; no, I had Ocular Proof of his Ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Then I am moſt unhappy; my Brother was the only Pledge of Faith betwixt us, if he has forfeited your Favour, I have no Title to your Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You wrong my Friendſhip, Iſabella; Your own Merit intitles you to every thing within my Power.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Generous Maid—But may I not know what Grounds you have to think my Brother Falſe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Another time.—But tell me, Iſabella, how can I ſerve you?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Thus then—The Gentleman that brought me hither, I have ſeen and talk'd with, upon the Terreiro de paſſa this Morning, and find him a Man of Senſe Generoſity, and good Humour, in ſhort he is every Thing that I cou'd like for a Husband, and I have diſpatch'd Mrs. Flora to bring him hither; I hope you'll forgive the Liberty I have taken.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Hither, to what Purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: To the great univerſal Purpoſe Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Matrimony! Why do you deſign to ask him?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: No, Violante, you muſt do that for me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I thank you for the Favour you deſign me, but deſire to be excus'd: I manage my own Affairs too ill, to be truſted with thoſe of other People; beſides, if my Father ſhou'd find a Stranger here, it might make him hurry me into a Monaſtery immediately; I can't for my Life admire your Conduct, to encourage a Perſon altogether unknown to you.—'Twas very Imprudent to meet him this Morning, but much more ſo, to ſend for him hither, knowing what Inconveniency you have already drawn upon me.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I am not inſenſible how far my Misfortunes have embarrraſt you; and if you pleaſe, ſacrifice my Quiet to your own.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Unkindly urg'd—Have I not preferr'd your Happineſs to every Thing that's dear to me.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
I know thou haſt—Then do not deny me this laſt Requeſt, which in a few Hours perhaps, may render
my Condition, able to clear thy Fame, and bring my Brother to thy Feet for Pardon.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I wiſh you don't repent of this Intrigue. I ſuppoſe he knows you are the ſame Woman that he brought in here laſt Night.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Not a Syllable of that, I met him vail'd, and to prevent his knowing the Houſe, I order'd Mrs. Flora to bring him by the back Door into the Garden.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: The very Way which Felix comes, If they ſhould meet, there would be fine Work—Indeed my Dear I can't approve of your Deſign.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Madam the Colonel waits your Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How durſt you go upon ſuch a Meſſage Miſtreſs without acquainting me.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Tis too late to diſpute that now, dear Violante, I acknowledge the Raſhneſs of the Action—But conſider the Neceſſity of my Deliverance.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: That is indeed a weighty Conſideration, well, what am I to do.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: In the next Room I'll give you Inſtructions, in the mean time Mrs. Flora ſhow the Colonel into this.
sp.stage: (Exit Flora one Way, and Iſabella and Violante another.)

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The Lady will wait on you preſently Sir,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Very well—This is a very fruitful Soil, I have not been here quite four and twenty Hours, and I have three Intrigues upon my Hands already, but I hate the Chaſe, without partaking the Game. (Enter Violante vail'd.) Ha, a fine ſiz'd Woman—Pray Heaven ſhe proves Handſome—I am come to obey your Ladyſhip's Commands.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If you be not very unreaſonable indeed, Madam; a Man is but a Man.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay, We have no Time for Compliments, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I underſtand you, Madam—Montre moy votre Chambre.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay, nay, hold Colonel, my Bed-Chamber is not to be enter'd without a certain Purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Purchaſe! Humph, This is ſome kept Miſtreſs, I ſuppoſe; who induſtriouſly lets out her leiſure Hours. (Aſide.) Look ye, Madam, you muſt conſider we Soldiers are not over ſtock'd with Money.—But we make ample Satisfaction in Love; we have a world of Courage upon our Hands now, you know:—Then prithy uſe a Conſcience, and I'll try if my Pocket can come up to your Price.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay, don't give your ſelf the trouble of drawing your Purſe Colonel, my Deſign is level'd at your Perſon, if that be at your own diſpoſal.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, that it is Faith Madam, and I'll ſettle it as firmly upon thee.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: As Law can do it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hang Law in love Affairs, thou ſhalt have Right and Title to it out of pure Inclination.—A Matrimonial Hint again! Gad, I fancy the Women have a Project on foot to tranſplant the Union into Portugal.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Then you have an averſion to Matrimony, Colonel; did you never ſee a Woman, in all your Travels, that you cou'd like for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A very odd Queſtion.—Do you really expect that I ſhou'd ſpeak Truth now?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I do, if you expect to be ſo dealt with, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why then,——Yes.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Is ſhe in your own Country, or this?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This is a very pretty kind of a Catechiſm; but I don't conceive which way it turns to Edification: In this Town I believe Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Her Name is.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, How is ſhe call'd, Madam!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay, I ask you that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh, ho, why ſhe is call'd—Pray Madam, how is it you Spell your Name?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh, Colonel, I am not the happy Woman, nor do I wiſh it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, I'm ſorry for that.—What the Devil does ſhe mean by all theſe Queſtions?(Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Come Colonel, for once be Sincere.—Perhaps you may not repent it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Faith Madam, I have an Inclination to Sincerity, but I'm afraid you'll call my Manners in Queſtion: This is like to be but a ſilly Adventure, here's ſo much Sincerity required. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Not at all; I prefer Truth before Compliment in this Affair.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why then to be plain with you, Madam, a Lady laſt Night wounded my Heart by a Fall from a Window, whoſe Perſon I cou'd be contented to take, as my Father took my Mother, till Death us doth part:—But who ſhe is, or how diſtinguiſh'd, whether Maid, Wife, or Widow I can't inform you, perhaps you are ſhe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Not to keep you in ſuſpence, I am not She, but I can give you an Account of Her; that Lady is a Maid of Condition, has ten Thouſand Pounds; and if you are a ſingle Man, her Perſon, and Fortune are at your Service.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I accept the Offer with the higheſt Tranſports; but ſay my charming Angel, art thou not ſhe. (offers to Embrace her.) This is a lucky Adventure. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Once again, Colonel, I tell you I am not ſhe.—
But at Six, this Evening you ſhall find her on the Terriere de paſſa, with a white Handkerchief in her Hand; get a Prieſt ready, and you know the reſt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ſhall infallibly obſerve your Directions, Madam.

div.stage: Enter Flora haſtily, and Whiſpers Violante, who ſtarts and ſeems ſurpiz'd.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ha Felix, croſſing the Garden, ſay you, what ſhall I do now?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You ſeem ſurpriz'd Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh, Colonel, my Father is coming hither, an if he finds you here I am ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Odſlife Madam, thruſt me any where, can't I go out this way?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No, no, no, he comes that way, how ſhall I prevent their Meeting? Here, here, ſtep into my Bed-Chamber and be ſtill, as you value her you love; don't ſtir till you've Notice, as ever you hope to have her in your Arms.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: On that Condition I'll not breath.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I wonder where my Dog of a Servant is all this while.—But ſhe's at Home I find.—How coldly ſhe regards me.—You look Violante as if the ſight of me were troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Can I do otherways, when you have the Aſſurance to approach me, after what I ſaw to Day.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p:
Aſſurance, rather call it good Nature, after what I heard laſt Night; but ſuch regard to Honour, have I in my Love to you, I cannot bear to be ſuſpected, nor ſuffer you to entertain falſe Notions of my Truth, without endeavouring to convince you of my Innocence, ſo much good Nature have I more than you Violante.—Pray give me leave to ask your Woman
man one Queſtion; my Man aſſures me ſhe was the Perſon you ſaw at my Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I confeſs it, Madam, and ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Impudent Baggage, not to undeceive me ſooner, what Buſineſs cou'd you have there?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Liſſardo and ſhe it ſeems imitate You and I.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I love to follow the Example of my Betters, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I hope I am juſtify'd.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Since we are to part, Felix, there needed no Juſtification.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Methinks you talk of parting, as a Thing indifferent to you; can you forget how I have lov'd?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I wiſh I cou'd forget my own Paſſion; I ſhou'd with leſs Concern remember yours.—But for Mrs. Flora.—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You muſt forgive her;—Muſt did I ſay? I fear I have no Power to Impoſe, tho' the Injury was done to me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: 'Tis harder to Pardon an Injury done to what we love than to our ſelves, but at your Requeſt, Felix, I do forgive her; go watch my Father, Flora, leaſt he ſhou'd wake, and ſurprize us.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Doſt thou then love me, Violante?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What need of Repetition from my Tongue, when every Look confeſſes what you ask?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Oh! Let no Man judge of Love but thoſe who feel it, what wondrous Magick lies in one kind Look.—One tender Word deſtroys a Lover's Rage, and melts his fierceſt Paſſion into ſoft Complaint. Oh the Window, Violante, woud'ſt thou but clear that one Suſpicion!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Prithy no more of that, my Felix, a little time ſhall bring thee perfect Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Well Violante, on that Condition you think no more of a Monaſtery.—I'll wait with Patience for his Mighty Secret.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ah Felix, Love generally gets the better of Religion in us Women▪ Reſolutions made in heat of Paſſion, ever diſſolve upon Reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh Madam, Madam, Madam, my Lord your Father has been in the Garden, and lock'd the back Door, and comes muttering to himſelf this way.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Then we are caught: Now Felix we are undone.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Heavens forbid, this is moſt unlucky; let me ſtep into your Bed-Chamber, he won't look under the Bed; there I may conceal my ſelf.
sp.stage: (runs to the Door, and puſhes it open a little.)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My Stars! If he goes in there he'll find the Colonel.—No, no, Felix, that's no ſafe Place, my Father often goes thither; and ſhou'd you Cough, or Sneeze, we are loſt.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Either my Eyes deceiv'd me, or I ſaw a Man within, I'll watch him cloſe.—She ſhall deal with the Devil, if ſhe conveys him out without my Knowledge. (Aſide.) what ſhall I do then?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Bleſs me, how I tremble!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh, Invention, Invention!—I have it Madam, here, here, here Sir, off with your Sword, and I'll fetch you a Diſguiſe.
sp.stage: (Runs in and fetches out a Riding-Hood.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Ay, ay, any Thing to avoid Don Pedro.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! Quick, quick, quick, I ſhall die with Apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Beſure you don't ſpeak a Word!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Not for the Indies.—But I ſhall obſerve you cloſer than you imagine. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: (Within.) Violante where are you, Child, (Enter Don Pedro.) Why, how came the Garden. Door open? Ha! how now, who have we here?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Humph, he'll certainly diſcover him. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis my Mother, and pleaſe you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Your Mother! By St. Anthony ſhe's a ſtrapper; why, you are a Dwarf to her.—How many Children have you good Woman?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! If he ſpeaks we are loſt. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh! Dear Senior, ſhe can't hear you, ſhe has been Deaf theſe twenty Years.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Alas poor Woman.—Why, you Muffle her up as if ſhe were Blind too.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Wou'd I were fairly off. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Turn up her Hood.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Undone for ever.—St. Anthony forbid: Oh Sir, ſhe has the dreadfulleſt unlucky Eyes.—Pray don't look upon them, I made her keep her Hood ſhut on Purpoſe.—Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Eyes! Why, what's the Matter with her Eyes?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My poor Mother, Sir, is much afflicted with the Cholick; and about two Months ago ſhe had it grievouſly in her Stomach, and was over-perſuaded to take a Dram of filthy Engliſh Geneva.—Which immediately flew up into her Head, and caus'd ſuch a Defluxion in her Eyes, that ſhe cou'd never ſince bear the Day-Light.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Say you ſo.—Poor Woman!—Well, make her ſit down, Violante, and give her a Glaſs of Wine.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Let her Daughter give her a Glaſs below, Sir, for my Part, ſhe has frighted me ſo, I ſhan't be my ſelf theſe two Hours. I am ſure her Eyes are evil Eyes.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Well hinted.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Well, well, do ſo, evil Eyes, there is no evil Eyes Child.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I'm glad he's gone.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Haſt thou heard the News, Violante?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What News, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Why, Vaſquez tells me that Don Lopez's Daughter Iſabella, is run away from her Father, that Lord has very ill Fortune with his Children.—Well, I'm glad my Daughter has no Inclination to Mankind, that my Houſe is plagu'd with no Suitors. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: This is the firſt Word I ever heard of it, I pity her Frailty.—

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Well ſaid Violante.—Next Week I intend thy Happineſs ſhall begin.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I don't intend to ſtay ſo long, I thank you, Pa, pa. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: My Lady Abbeſs writes Word ſhe longs to ſee thee, and has provided every Thing in order for thy Reception.—Thou wilt lead a happy Life my Girl.—Fifty times before that of Matrimony, where an extravagant Coxcomb might make a Beggar of thee, or an ill Natur'd ſurly Dog break thy Heart.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Break her Heart! She had as good have her Bones broke as to be a Nun; I am ſure I had, rather of the two.—You are wondrous kind, Sir, but if I had ſuch a Father, I know what I wou'd do.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Why, what wou'd you do Minx, ha?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I wou'd tell him I had as good Right and Title to the Laws of Nature, and the End of the Creation, as he had.—

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: You wou'd Miſtreſs, who the Devil doubts it! A good Aſſurance is a Chamber-Maid's Coat of Arms; and lying, and contriving the Supporters.—Your Inclinations are on Tip-toe it ſeems.—If I were your Father, Houſewife, I'd have a Penance enjoyn'd you, ſo ſtrict, that you ſhou'd not be able to turn you in your Bed for a Month.—You are enough to ſpoil your Lady Houſewife, if ſhe had not abundance of Devotion.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Fye Flora, Are not you aſham'd to talk thus to my Father? You ſaid Yeſterday you wou'd be glad to go with me into the Monaſtery.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: She go with thee! No, no, ſhe's enough to Debauch the whole Convent.—Well Child, remember what I ſaid to thee, next Week.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, and what am I to do this too.— (Aſide. I am all Obedience, Sir, I care not how ſoon I change my Condition.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: But little does he think what Change ſhe means. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Well ſaid Violante.—I am glad to find her ſo willing to leave the World, but it is wholly owing to my Prudent Management; did ſhe know that ſhe might command her Fortune when ſhe came at Age, or upon Day of Marriage, Perhaps ſhe'd change her Note.—But I have always told her that her Grand-Father left it with this Proviſo, That ſhe turn'd Nun, now a ſmall Part of this twenty Thouſand Pounds provides for her in the Nunnery, and the reſt is my own; there is nothing to be got in this Life without Policy. (Aſide.) Well Child, I am going into the Country for two or three Days, to ſettle ſome Affairs with thy Unkle.—And then.—Come help me on with my Cloak, Child.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: So now for the Colonel. (Goes to the Chamber Door.) Hiſt, hiſt Colonel. (Colonel peeping. )

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Is the Coaſt clear?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, if you can Climb, for you muſt get over the Waſh-Houſe, and Jump from the Garden-Wall into the Street.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I don't value my Neck if my Incogita Anſwers but thy Lady's Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Good bye Violante, take Care of thy ſelf, Child.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I wiſh you a good Journey, Sir.—Now to ſet my Priſoner at Liberty.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I have lain Perdue under the Stairs, till I watch'd the old Man out.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, you may appear.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: May he ſo, Madam.—I had Cauſe for my Suſpicion, I find, treacherous Woman.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ha, Felix here! Nay then, all's diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (Draws.) Villain, who e'er thou art, come out I charge thee, and take the Reward of thy Adulterous Errand.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay.—Nothing but the Secret which I have Sworn to keep can reconcile this Quarrel. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: A Coward! Nay, then I'll fetch you out, think not to hide thy ſelf; no, by St. Anthony, an Altar ſhould not Protect thee, even there I'd reach thy Heart, tho' all the Saints were arm'd in thy Defence.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Defend me Heaven! What ſhall I do? I muſt diſcover Iſabella, or here will be Murder.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I have help'd the Colonel off clear, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou my Girl? Then I am arm'd.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Where has the Devil in Complaiſance to your Sex convey'd him from my juſt Reſentments?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Him, who do you mean my dear inquiſitive Spark? Ha, ha, ha, ha, will you never leave theſe Jealous Whims?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Will you never ceaſe to Impoſe upon me?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You impoſe upon your ſelf, my Dear, do you think I did not ſee you? Yes, I did, and reſolv'd to put this Trick upon you; I knew you'd take the Hint, and ſoon relapſe into your wonted Error: how eaſily your Jealouſy is fir'd, I ſhall have a bleſſed Life with you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Was there nothing in it then, but only to try me?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Won't you believe your Eyes?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: No, becauſe I find they have deceiv'd me; well, I am convinc'd that Faith is as neceſſary in Love as in Religion; for the Moment a Man lets a Woman know her Conqueſt, he reſigns his Senſes, and ſees nothing but what ſhe'd have him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And as ſoon as that Man finds his Love return'd, ſhe becomes as errant a Slave, as if ſhe had already ſaid after the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: The Prieſt, Violante, wou'd diſſipate thoſe Fears which cauſe theſe Quarrels; when wilt thou make me Happy?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: To-Morrow I will tell thee, my Father is gone for two or three Days to my Uncles, we have time enough to finiſh our Affairs.—But prithy leave me now, for I expect ſome Ladies to Viſit me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: If you Command it.—Fly ſwift ye Hours, and bring to-Morrow on.—You deſire I wou'd leave you, Violante.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I do at preſent.

l.hi: So much you reign the Sovereign of my Soul,
That I Obey without the leaſt Controul.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
I am glad my Brother and you are reconcil'd my Dear, and the Colonel eſcap'd without his knowledge; I was frighted out of my Wits when I heard him return.—I know not how to expreſs my Thanks Woman.—
for what you ſuffer'd for my Sake, my grateful Acknowlegements ſhall ever wait you; and to the World proclaim the Faith, Truth, and Honour of a Woman—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Prithy don't Compliment thy Friend, Iſabella.—You heard the Colonel I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Every Syllable, and am pleas'd to find I do not Love in vain.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Thou haſt caught his Heart it ſeems; and an Hour hence may ſecure his Perſon.—Thou haſt made haſty Work on't, Girl.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: From thence I draw my Happineſs, we ſhall have no Accounts to make up after Conſummation.

l.hi: She who for Years, protracts her Lover's Pain,
And makes him Wiſh, and Wait, and Sigh in vain,
To be his Wife, when late ſhe gives Conſent,
Finds half his Paſſion was in Courtſhip ſpent;
Whilſt they who boldly all Delays remove,
Find every Hour a freſh ſupply of Love.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: THIS Hour has been propitious, I am reconcil'd to Violante, and you aſſure me Antonio is out of Danger.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your Satisfaction is doubly mine.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What Haſte you made Sirrah, to bring me Word if Violante went home?

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: I can give you very good Reaſons for my ſtay Sir.—Yes Sir, ſhe went home.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O! Your Maſter knows that, for he has been there himſelf Liſſardo.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Sir, may I beg the Favour of your Ear.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What have you to ſay?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha, Felix changes Colour at Liſſardo's News. What can it be?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: A Scots Footman, that belongs to Colonel Britton, an Acquaintance of Frederick's ſay you; the Devil! If ſhe be falſe, by Heaven I'll trace her. Prithy Frederick do you know one Colonel Britton a Scotſman?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, why do you ask me?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Nay no great Matter, but my Man tells me that he has had ſome little Difference with a Servant of his, that's all.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
He is a good harmleſs innocent Fellow, I am
ſorry for it; the Colonel lodges in my Houſe, I knew him formerly in England, and met him here by Accident laſt Night, and gave him an Invitation home, he is a Gentleman of a good Eſtate, beſides his Commiſſion; of excellent Principles, and ſtrict Honour I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Is he a Man of Intrigue?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Like other Men I ſuppoſe, here he comes.—
Colonel, I began to think I had loſt you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: —And not without ſome Reaſons if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: There's no Danger of a fine Gentleman's being loſt in this Town, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col,
sp.p: That Compliment don't belong to me Sir. But I aſſure you I have been very near being run away with.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who attempted it?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Faith I know her not—Only that ſhe is a charming Woman, I mean as much as I ſaw of her.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My Heart ſwells with Apprehenſion.—Some accidental Rencounter.—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A Tavern I ſuppoſe adjuſted the Matter.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A Tavern! No, no Sir, ſhe is above that Rank I aſſure you, this Nymph ſleeps in a Velvet Bed, and Lodgings every Way agreeable.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Ha, a Velvet Bed!—I thought you ſaid but now Sir, you knew her not.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No more I don't Sir.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: How came you then ſo well acquainted with her Bed?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ay, ay, come, come, unfold.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why then you muſt know Gentleman, that I was convey'd to her Lodgings, by one of Cupids Emiſſaries, call'd a Chambermaid, in a Chair, thro' fifty blind Alleys, who by the help of a Key let me into a Garden.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: S'Death, a Garden, this muſt be Violante's Garden. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: From thence conducted me into a ſpacious Room, then dropt me a Courteſie, told me her Lady would wait on me preſently, ſo without unvailing modeſtly withdrew.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Damn her Modeſty; this was Flora. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, how then Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then Sir, immediately from another Door iſſued forth a Lady, arm'd at both Eyes, from whence ſuch Showers of Darts fell round me, that had I not been cover'd with the Shield of another Beauty, I had infallibly fall'n a Martyr to her Charms; for you muſt know I juſt ſaw her Eyes, Eyes did I ſay? No, no, hold, I ſaw but one Eye, tho' I ſuppoſe it had a Fellow, equally as killing.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: But how came you to ſee her Bed Sir? S'Death this Expectation gives a thouſand Racks. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why upon her Maid's giving Notice her Father was coming ſhe thruſt me into the Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Upon her Father's coming?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, ſo ſhe ſaid, but putting my Ear to the Keyhole of the Door, I found it was another Lover.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Confound the Jilt! 'Twas ſhe without diſpute. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah poor Colonel, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I diſcover'd they had had a Quarrel, but whether they were reconcil'd or not, I can't tell, for the ſecond Alarm brought the Father in good earneſt, and had like to have made the Gentleman and I acquainted, but ſhe found ſome other Stratagem to convey him out.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Contagion ſeize her, and make her Body ugly as her Soul. There's nothing left to doubt of now,—'Tis plain 'twas ſhe,—Sure he knows me, and takes this Method to inſult me, S'Death I cannot bear it. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
So when ſhe had diſpatch'd her old Lover, ſhe
paid you a Viſit in her Bed-Chamber, ha, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, Pox take the impertinent Puppy, he ſpoil'd my Diverſion, I ſaw her no more.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Very fine! Give me Patience Heaven, or I ſhall burſt with Rage. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That was hard.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, what was worſe, the Nymph that introduc'd me convey'd me out again over the Top of a high Wall, where I ran the Danger of having my Neck broke, for the Father it ſeems had lock'd the Door by which I enter'd.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: That Way I miſs'd him:—Damn her Invention. (Aſide.) Pray Colonel was this the ſame Lady you met upon the Terrerio de paſſa this Morning?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Faith I can't tell Sir, I had a Deſign to know who that Lady was, but my Dog of a Footman, whom I had order'd to watch her home, fell faſt a Sleep—I gave him a good beating for his Neglect, and I have never ſeen the Raſcal ſince.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Where have you been Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Troth Iſe been ſeeking yee an like yer Honor theſe twa Hoors an meer, I bring yee glad Teedings Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What have you found the Lady?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Geud Faith ha I Sir—an Shee's call'd Donna Violante, and her Parent Don Pedro de Mendoſa, an gin yee wull gang wa mi, an't like ye'r honor, Iſe mak yee ken the Huſe right weel.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Oh, Torture! Torture!(Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha! Violante! That's the Lady's Name of the Houſe where my Incognita is, ſure it could not be her, at leaſt it was not the ſame Houſe I'm confident. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Violante! 'Tis falſe, I wou'd not have you credit him Colonel.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: The Deel bruſt my Blader, Sir gin I lee.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Sirrah, I ſay you do lye, and I'll make you eat it you Dog. (kicks him) and if your Maſter will juſtify you—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Not I faith Sir—I anſwer for no body's Lyes, but my own, if you pleaſe kick him again.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: But gin he dus, Iſe ne tak it Sir, gin he was a thouſand Spaniards.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ow'd you a beating Sirrah, and I'm oblig'd to this Gentleman for taking the Trouble off my Hands, therefore ſay no more, d'ye hear Sir?(Aſide to Gibby.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Troth de I Sir, and feel tee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This muſt be a Miſtake Colonel, for I know Violante perfectly well, and I'm certain ſhe would not meet you upon the Terriero de paſſa.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Don't be too poſitive Frederick, now I have ſome Reaſons to believe it was that very Lady.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You'd very much oblige me Sir, if you'd let me know theſe Reaſons.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Sir, I ſay I have a right to enquire into thoſe Reaſons you ſpeak off.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha, ha, really Sir I cannot conceive how you, or any Man can have a right to enquire into my Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Sir I have a Right to every Thing that relates to Violante—And he that traduces her Fame, and refuſes to give his Reaſons for't is a Villain.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What the Devil have I been doing; now Bliſters on my Tongue, by Dozens. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Prithy Felix don't quarrel till you know for what, this is all a Miſtake I'm poſitive.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Look ye Sir, that I dare draw my Sword I think will admit of no Diſpute.—But tho' fighting's my Trade, I'm not in Love with it, and think it more honourable to decline this Buſineſs, than purſue it. This may be a Miſtake, however I'll give you my
Honour never to have any Affair directly, or indirectly with Violante provided ſhe is your Violante; but if there ſhou'd happen to be another of her Name I hope you wou'd not engroſs all the Violantes in the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Your Vanity has given me ſufficient Reaſons to believe I'm not miſtaken, I'm not to be impos'd upon Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nor I bully'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Bully'd! S'Death, ſuch another Word, and I'll nail thee to the Wall.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: (Draws) Say ne meer Mon, aw my Sol here's Twa, to Twa, dona fear Sir, Gibby ſtonds by yee for the Honor a Scotland.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: By St. Anthony you ſhan't fight (Interpoſes) on bare Suſpicion, be certain of the Injury, and then.—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: That I will this Moment, and then Sir—I hope you are to be found—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: When ever you pleaſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: S'bleed Sir, there neer was Scotſman yet that ſham'd to ſhew his Face. (ſtrutting about.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 Quarrels ſpring up like Muſhrooms, in a Minute: Violante, and he, was but juſt reconcil'd, and you have furniſh'd him with freſh Matter for falling out again, and I am certain Colonel, Gibby is in the Wrong.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Gin I be Sir, the Mon that tald me leed, and gin he dud, the Deel be my Landlard, Hell my Winter Quarters, and a Rope my Winding Sheet, Gin I dee no lik him as lang as I can hold a Stick in my Hond, now ſee yee.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am ſorry for what I have ſaid, for the Lady's Sake, but who could divine, that ſhe was his Miſtreſs, prithy who is this warm Spark?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
He is the Son of one of our Grandees, nam'd Don Lopez de Pementell, a very honeſt Gentleman, but ſomething paſſionate in what relates to his Love.—He
is an only Son, which perhaps may be one Reaſon for indulging his Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: When Parents have but one Child, they either make a Madman, or a Fool of him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: He is not the only Child, he has a Siſter, but I think thro' the Severity of his Father, who would have married her againſt her Inclination, ſhe has made her eſcape, and notwithſtanding he has offer'd five hundred Pounds, he can get no Tydings of her.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha! How long has ſhe been miſſing?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay, but ſince laſt Night, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Laſt Night! The very Time! How went ſhe?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No body can tell, they conjecture thro' the Window.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'm tranſported! This muſt be the Lady I caught; What ſort of a Woman is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Middle ſiz'd, a lovely brown, a fine pouting Lip, Eyes that roul and languiſh, and ſeem to ſpeak the exquiſite Pleaſure that her Arms could give!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh! I'm fir'd with his Deſcription—'Tis the very ſhe—What's her Name?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Iſabella—You are tranſported Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have a natural Tendency in me to the Fleſh, thou know'ſt, and who can hear of Charms ſo exquiſite, and yet remain unmov'd? Oh, how I long for the appointed Hour! I'll to the Terreiro de paſſa, and wait my Happineſs, if ſhe fails to meet me, I'll once more attempt to find her at Violante's in ſpite of her Brother's Jealouſy. (Aſide) Dear Frederick I beg your Pardon but I had forgot, I was to meet a Gentleman upon Buſineſs at Five, I'll endeavour to diſpatch him, and wait on you again as ſoon as poſſible.—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your humble Servant Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Gibby I have no Buſineſs with you at preſent.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p:
That's weel—naw will I gang and ſeck this Loon, and gar him gang with me to Don Pedro's
Huſe—Gin he will no gang of himſel, Iſe gar him gang by the Lug Sir; Godſwarbit Gibby hates a Lear.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: The Hour draws on Violante, and now my Heart begins to fail me, but I reſolve to venture for all that.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What does your Courage ſink Iſabella?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Only the Force of Reſolution a little retreated, but I'll rally it again for all that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Don Felix is coming up Madam!

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: My Brother! Which way ſhall I get out—Diſpatch him as ſoon as you can dear Violante.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I will. (Enter Felix in a ſurly Poſture.) Felix, what brings you back ſo ſoon, did not I ſay to-morrow?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My Paſſion choaks me, I cannot ſpeak, oh I ſhall burſt!(Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Bleſs me! are you not well my Felix?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Yes,—No,—I don't know what I am.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Hey Day! What's the Matter now? Another jealous Whim!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: With what an Air ſhe carries it.—I ſweat at her Impudence. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: If I were in your Place, Felix, I'd chuſe to ſtay at home, when theſe Fits of Spleen were upon me, and not trouble ſuch Perſons as are not oblig'd to bear with them.
sp.stage: (Here he affects to be careleſs of her.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I am very ſenſible Madam of what you mean: I diſturb you no doubt, but were I in a better Humour I ſhou'd not incommode you leſs. I am but too well convinc'd, that you could eaſily diſpence with my Viſit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
When you behave your ſelf as you ought to do no Company ſo welcome—But when you reſerve me for your ill Nature, I wave your Merit, and conſider
what's due to my ſelf—And I muſt be ſo free to tell you Felix, that theſe Humors of yours will abate, if not abſolutely deſtroy the very Principles of Love.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (Riſing) And I muſt be ſo free to tell you Madam, that ſince you have made ſuch ill Returns to the Reſpect that I have paid you, all you do ſhall be indifferent to me for the Future, and you ſhall find me abandon your Empire with ſo little Difficulty, that I'll convince the World your Chains are not ſo hard to break as your Vanity would tempt you to believe—I cannot brook the Provocations you give.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: This is not to be born—Inſolent! You abandon! You! Whom I have ſo often forbad ever to ſee me more! Have you not fall'n at my Feet? Implor'd my Favour and Forgiveneſs—Did you not trembling wait, and wiſh, and ſigh, and ſwear your ſelf into my Heart? Ingrateful Man! If my Chains are ſo eaſily broke as you pretend, then you are the ſillieſt Coxcomb living, you did not break 'em long ago; and I muſt think him capable of brooking any thing on whom ſuch Uſage could make no Impreſſion.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: (Peeping.) A Duce take your Quarrels ſhe'll never think on me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I always believed, Madam, my Weakneſs was the greateſt Addition to your Power, you would be leſs Imperious, had my Inclination been leſs forward to oblige you.—You have indeed forbad me your Sight, but your Vanity even then aſſured you I would return, and I was Fool enough to feed your Pride.—Your Eyes, with all their boaſted Charms, have acquired the greateſt Glory in conquering me.—And the brighteſt Paſſage of your Life is, wounding this Heart with ſuch Arms as pierce but few Perſons of my Rank.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Matchleſs Arrogance! True Sir, I ſhould have kept Meaſures better with you, if the Conqueſt had been worth preſerving, but we eaſily hazard what
gives us no Pain to looſe.—As for my Eyes, you are miſtaken if you think they have vanquiſhed none but you; there are Men above your boaſted Rank who have confeſs'd their Power, when their Misfortune in pleaſing you made them obtain ſuch a diſgraceful Victory.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Yes Madam, I am no Stranger to your Victories.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And what you call the brighteſt Paſſage of my Life, is not the leaſt glorious Part of yours.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, don't put your ſelf into a Paſſion, Madam, for I aſſure you after this Day I ſhall give you no Trouble.—You may meet your Sparks on the Terriero de Paſſa at Four in the Morning, without the leaſt Regard of mine.—For when I quit your Chamber, the World ſhan't bring me back.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I am ſo well pleas'd with your Reſolution, I don't care how ſoon you take your leave.—But what you mean by the Terreiro de paſſa at Four in the Morning I can't gueſs.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: No, no, no, not you.—You was not upon the Terriero de paſſa at Four this Morning.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No, I was not; but if I was, I hope I may Walk where I pleaſe, and at what Hour I pleaſe without asking you leave.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Oh, doubtleſs Madam! And you might meet Colonel Britton there, and afterwards ſend your Emiſſary to fetch him to your Houſe.—And upon your Father's coming in, thruſt him into your Bed-Chamber—without asking my leave. 'Tis no Buſineſs of mine if you are expoſed among all the Foot-Men in Town.—Nay, if they Ballad you, and cry you about at a half-Penny a piece.—They may without my Leave.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Audacious! Don't provoke me—Don't; my Reputation is not to be ſported with (Going up to him.) at this rate.—No Sir, it is not. (burſts into Tears.) Inhuman Felix!—Oh Iſabella, what a Train of Ills haſt thou brought on me?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p:
Ha! I cannot bear to ſee her Weep.—A Woman's
Tears are far more Fatal than our Swords. (Aſide.) Oh Violante.—S'Death! What a Dog am I? Now have I no Power to ſtir:—Doſt not thou know ſuch a Perſon as Colonel Britton? Prithy tell me, did'ſt not thou meet him at Four this Morning upon the Terreiro de paſſa?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Were it not to clear my Fame, I would not anſwer thee thou black Ingrate!—But I cannot bear to be reproach'd with what I even Bluſh to think of, much leſs to act; by Heaven I have not ſeen the Terreiro de paſſa this Day.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Did not a Scots Foot-Man attack you in the Street neither Violante?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Yes, but he miſtook me for another, or he was Drunk, I know not which.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And do not you know this Scots Colonel?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Pray ask me no more Queſtions, this Night ſhall clear my Reputation, and leave you without Excuſe for your baſe Suſpicions; more than this I ſhall not ſatisfie you, therefore Pray leave me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Didſt thou ever love me, Violante?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I'll anſwer nothing.—You was in haſte to be gone juſt now, I ſhould be very well pleas'd to be alone, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I ſhall not long interrupt your Contemplation.—Stubborn to the laſt. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Did ever Woman involve her ſelf as I have done?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Now wou'd I give one of my Eyes to be Friends with her, for ſomething whiſpers to my Soul ſhe is not guilty.— (He pauſes, then pulls a Chair, and ſits by her at a little diſtance, looking at her ſome time without ſpeaking—Then draws a little nearer to her.) Give me your Hand at parting however Violante, won't you, (Here he lays his open upon her Knee ſeveral times.) won't you—won't you—won't you?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: (Half regarding him.) Won't I do what?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You know what I wou'd have, Violante, Oh my Heart!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: (Smiling.) I thought my Chains were eaſily broke.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (Draws his Chair cloſe to her, and kiſſes her Hand in a Rapture.) Too well thou knoweſt thy Strength.—Oh my charming Angel, my Heart is all thy own, forgive my haſty Paſſion, 'tis the tranſport of a Love ſincere!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Bid Sancho get a New Wheel to my Chariot preſently.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Bleſs me! My Father return'd! What ſhall we do now Felix? We are ruin'd, paſt Redemption.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: No, no, no, my Love, I can leap from thy Cloſet Window.
sp.stage: (Runs to the Door where Iſabella is, who claps too the Door, and Bolts it within ſide.)

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: (Peeping.) Say you ſo, But I ſhall prevent you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Confuſion! Some Body bolts the Door within ſide, I'll ſee who you have conceal'd here if I dye for't; Oh Violante! Haſt thou again ſacrific'd me to my Rival?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: By Heaven thou haſt no Rival in my Heart, let that ſuffice—nay ſure you will not let my Father find You here—Diſtraction!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Indeed but I ſhall—except You command this Door to be open'd, and that way conceal me from his Sight.
sp.stage: (He ſtruggles with her to come at the Door.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Hear me Felix—tho' I were ſure the refuſing what you ask would ſeparate us for ever, by all that's powerful You ſhould not enter here, either You do love me, or You do not, convince me by Your Obedience.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: That's not the Matter in debate—I will know who is in this Cloſet, let the Conſequence be what it will. Nay, nay, nay, You ſtrive in vain, I will go in.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You ſhall not go in—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Hey day! What's here to do! I will go in, and You ſhan't go in,—and I will go in—why who are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! What ſhall I ſay now!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Don Felix, pray what's your Buſineſs in my Houſe? Ha Sir?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh Sir, what Miracle return'd you home ſo ſoon? Some Angel 'twas that brought my Father back to ſuccour the Diſtreſs'd—this Ruffian here I cannot call him Gentleman—has committed ſuch an uncommon rudeneſs, as the moſt profligate Wretch wou'd be aſham'd to own—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Ha, what the Devil does ſhe mean!(Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: As I was at my Devotion in my Cloſet, I heard a loud knocking at our Door, mix'd with a Woman's Voice, which ſeem'd to imply ſhe was in Danger—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I am confounded!(Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I flew to the Door with utmoſt ſpeed, where a Lady vail'd ruſhed in upon me, who falling on her Knees begg'd my Protection, from a Gentleman whom ſhe ſaid perſued her, I took Compaſſion on her Tears, and locked her into this Cloſet, but in the Surprize having left open the Door, this very Perſon whom You ſee, with his drawn Sword ran in; proteſting, if I refuſed to give her up to his Revenge, he'd force the Door.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What in the Name of Goodneſs, does ſhe mean to do! Hang me. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I ſtrove with him till I was out of Breath, and had You not come as You did he muſt have enter'd—but he's in Drink I ſuppoſe, or he could not have been guilty of ſuch an Indecorum. (Leering at Felix.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I am amazed!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: The Devil never fail'd a Woman at a Pinch, what a Tale has ſhe form'd in a Minute—in Drink quotha, a good Hint, I'll lay hold on't to bring my ſelf off. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Fie Don Felix! No ſooner rid of one Broil, but you are commencing another—to aſſault a Lady with a naked Sword, derogates much from the Character of a Gentleman, I aſſure You.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (Counterfeits Drunkenneſs) Who, I aſſault a Lady—upon Honour the Lady aſſaulted me Sir, and would have ſeiz'd this Body Politick upon the King's High-way—let her come out, and deny it if ſhe can—pray Sir command the Door to be open'd, and let her prove me a Lyar if ſhe knows how—I have been drinking right French Claret Sir, but I love my own Country for all that.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ay, ay, who doubts it Sir?—Open the Door Violante, and let the Lady come out,—come I warrant thee, he ſhan't hurt her.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Ay, now which way will ſhe come off!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: (Unlocks the Door) come forth Madam, none ſhall dare to touch your Vail—I'll convey You out with Safety, or looſe my Life—I hope ſhe underſtands me. (Aſide.

div.stage: Enter Iſabella Vail'd, and croſſes the Stage.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Excellent Girl!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: The Devil! A Woman! I'll ſee if ſhe be really ſo.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (Draws) Not a Step Sir till the Lady be paſt your Recovery.—I never ſuffer the Laws of Hoſpitality to be violated in my Houſe Sir.—I'll keep Don Felix here till you ſee her ſafe out Violante.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Get clear of my Father, and follow me to the Terreiro de Paſſa, where all Miſtakes ſhall be rectifyed. (Aſide to Felix.)

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Come Sir, you and I will take a Pipe and a Bottle together.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p:
Damn your Pipe Sir, I won't ſmoak—I hate Tobacco—Nor I, I, I, I won't drink Sir—No
nor I won't ſtay neither, and how will you help your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: As to ſmoaking, or drinking, you have your Liberty, but you ſhall ſtay Sir.
sp.stage: (Gets between him and the Door, Felix ſtrikes up his Heels and Exit.)

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Shall I ſo Sir—But I tell you old Gentleman I am in haſte to be married—And ſo God be with you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Go to the Devil—In haſte to be married quotha, thou art in a fine Condition to be married truly!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here's Don Lopez de Pimmentel to wait on you Senior.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What the Devil does he want? Bring him up he's in purſuit of his Son I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: I am glad to find you at Home, Don Pedro, I was told that you was ſeen upon the Road to——this Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That might be my Lord, but I had the Misfortune to break the Wheel of my Chariot, which oblig'd me to return—What is your Pleaſure with me my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: I am inform'd that my Daughter is in your Houſe, Don Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That's more than I know my Lord, but here was your Son juſt now as drunk as an Emperor.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: My Son drunk! I never ſaw him in Drink in my Life, where is he pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Gone to be married.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Married! To whom? I don't know that he courted any Body.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Nay I know nothing of that—Within there!
(Enter Servant.) bid my Daughter come hither ſhe'll tell you another Story my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: She's gone out in a Chair Sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Out in a Chair, what do you mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: As I ſay Sir, and Donna Iſabella went in another juſt before her.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: And Don Felix follow'd in another, I overheard them all, bid their Chairs go to the Terreiro de paſſa.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ha! What Buſineſs has my Daughter there? I am confounded, and know not what to think.—Within there.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: My Heart miſgives me plaguely—Call me a Alguzile, I'll perſue them ſtrait.

head.hi: SCENE changes to the Street before Don Pedro's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: I wiſh I could ſee Flora—Methinks I have an hankering Kindneſs after the Slut——We muſt be reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Aw my Sol, Sir, but Iſe blithe to find yee here now.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Ha! Brother! Give me thy Hand Boy.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Notſe faſt, ſe ye me—Brether me ne Brethers, I ſcorn a Lyar as muckle as a Theife, ſe ye now, and yee muſt gang intu • this Houſe with me, and juſtifie to Donna Violante's Face, that ſhe was the Lady that gang'd in here this Morn, ſe yee me, or the Deel ha my Sol, Sir, but ye and I ſhall be twa Folks.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Juſtify it to Donna Violante's Face, quotha, for what? Sure you don't know what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Troth de I, Sir, as weel as yee de, therefore come along, and mak no mear Words about it.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Why what the Devil do you mean? Don't you conſider you are in Portugal. Is the Fellow mad?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Fallow! Iſe none of yer Fallow, Sir, and gin this Place were Hell, id gar ye de me Juſtice, (Liſſ. going) nay the Deel a Feet ye gang.
sp.stage: (Lays hold of him, and Knocks again.)

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: How now! What makes you knock ſo loud?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Gin this be Don Pedro's Houſe, Sir, I wou'd ſpeak with Donna Violante his Doughter.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Ha! Don Pedro himſelf, I wiſh I were fairly off. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ha! What is it you want with my Daughter pray?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: An ſhe be your Doughter, an lik yer Honer, command her to come out, and anſwer for herſel now, and either juſtify or diſprove what this Shield told me this Morn.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: So, here will be a fine Piece of Work. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why what did he tell you, ha?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Be me Sol, Sir, Iſe tell you aw the Truth, my Maſter got a pratty Lady upon the how de yee call't—Paſſa—Here at Five this Morn, and he Gar me watch her heam—And in Troth I lodg'd her here, and meeting this ill favour'd Theife, ſe ye me, I ſpierd wha ſhe was—And he told me her Name was Donna Violante, Don Pedro de Mendoſa's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ha! My Daughter with a Man abroad at Five in the Morning, Death, Hell, and Furies, by St. Anthony I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Wunds Sir, ye put yer Saint intul bony Company.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Who is your Maſter ye Dog you? Adſheart I ſhall be trick'd of my Daughter, and my Money too, that's worſt of all.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Ye Dog you! Sblead, Sir, don't call Names—I wont tell you wha my Maſter is, ſe ye me now.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: And who are you Raſcal, that knows my Daughter ſo well? Ha!

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay to make him give this Scots Dog a good beating? (Aſide.) I know your Daughter, Senior. Not I, I never ſaw your Daughter in all my Life.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: (Knocks him down with his Fiſt.) Deel ha my Sol, Sar, gin ye get no your Carich for that Lye now.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: What hoa! Where are all my Servants? (Enter Servants on one ſide, Colonel, Felix, Iſabella, and Violante on the other ſide.) Raiſe the Houſe in purſuit of my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here ſhe comes, Senior.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hey Day! What is here to do?

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: This is the Loon lik Tik, and lik yer Honor, that ſent me Heam with a Lye this Morn.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come, come, 'tis all well Gibby, let him riſe.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: I am Thunder-ſtruck—and have not Power to ſpeak one Word.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: This is a Day of Jubilee, Liſſardo; no quarelling with him this Day.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: A Pox take his Fits.—Egad, theſe Brittons are but a Word and a Blow.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: So, have I found your Daughter; then you have not hang'd your ſelf yet I ſee.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But ſhe is married, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Married, Zounds to whom!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Even to your humble Servant, my Lord, if you pleaſe to give us your Bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Why hark ye Miſtreſs, are you really married?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Really ſo, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: And who are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: An honeſt North Britton by Birth, and a Colonel by Commiſſion, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: A Heretick! The Devil!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: She has play'd you a ſlippery Trick indeed my Lord.—Well my Girl thou haſt been to ſee thy Friend married.—Next Week thou ſhalt have a better Husband, my Dear. (To Violante.)

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Next Week is a little too ſoon Sir, I hope to live longer than that.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: What do you mean Sir? You have not made a Rib of my Daughter too, have you?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Indeed but he has, Sir, I know not how, but he took me in an unguarded Minute,—when my Thoughts were not over ſtrong for a Nunnery, Father.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Your Daughter has play'd you a ſlippery Trick too, Senior.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: But your Son ſhall be never the better for't my Lord, her twenty Thouſand Pounds was left on certain Conditions, and I'll not part with a Shilling.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: But we have a certain Thing call'd Law, ſhall make you do Juſtice, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Well we'll try that,—my Lord, much good may it do you with your Daughter in Law.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: I wiſh you much Joy of your Rib.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Frederick, Welcome!—I ſent for thee to be Witneſs of my good Fortune, and make one in a Country-Dance.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your Meſſenger has told me all, and I ſincerely ſhare in all your Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: To the Right about Frederick, wiſh thy Friend Joy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I do with all my Soul;—and Madam I congratulate your Deliverance.—Your Suſpicions are clear'd now, I hope Felix.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: They are, and I heartily ask the Colonel Pardon, and wiſh him Happy with my Siſter; for Love has taught me to know, that every Man's Happineſs conſiſts in chuſing for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: After that Rule, I fix here. (To Flora.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That's your Miſtake, I prefer my Lady's Service, and turn you over to her that pleaded Right and Title to you to Day.

sp.speaker: Liſſ.
sp.p: Chuſe proud Fool, I ſhan't ask you twice.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: What ſay ye now Laſs, will ye ge yer Maiden-Head to poor Gibby.—What ſay you, will ye Dance the Reel of Bogye with me?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: That I may not leave my Lady,—I take you at your Word.—And tho' our Wooing has been ſhort, I'll by her Example love you dearly.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Hark! I hear the Muſick, ſome Body has done us the Favour to ſend them, call them in.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Waunds this is bony Muſick.—How caw ye that Thing that ye pinch by the Craig, and tickle the Weam, and make it cry Grum, Grum.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh! that's a Guittar, Gibby.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Now my Violante, I ſhall Proclaim thy Vertues to the World.

l.hi: No more, let us Thy Sex's Conduct blame,
Since thou'rt a Proof to their eternal Fame,

sp.l: That Man has no Advantage but the Name.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: CUſtom with all our Modern Laws combin'd,
Has given ſuch Power deſpotick to Mankind,
That We have only ſo much Vertue now,
As they are pleas'd in favour to allow.
Thus like Mechanick Work we're us'd with Scorn,
And wound up only, for a preſent Turn;
Some are for having our whole Sex enſlav'd,
Affirming we've no Souls, and can't be ſav'd;
But were the Women all of my Opinion,
We'd ſoon ſhake off this falſe uſurp'd Dominion;
We'd make the Tyrants own, that we cou'd prove,
As fit for other Buſineſs as for Love.
Lord! What Prerogative might we obtain,
Could we from Yielding, a few Months refrain!
How fondly wou'd our ſtarving Lovers doat!
What Homage wou'd be paid to Petticoat!
'Twou'd be a Jeſt to ſee the change of Fate,
How we might all of Politicks Debate;
Promiſe, and Swear, what we ne'er meant to do,
And what's ſtill harder, keep your Secrets too.
Ay Marry! Keep a Secret ſays a Beau,
And ſneers at ſome ill-natur'd Wit below;
But Faith, if we ſhou'd tell but half we know,
There's many a ſpruce Young Fellow in this Place,
Would never more preſume to ſhow his Face;
Women are not ſo weak, whate'er Men prate;
How many tip top Beau's have had the Fate,
T'enjoy from Mamma's Secrets their Eſtate.
Which if Her early Folly had made known,
He'd rid behind the Coach, that's now His own.
But here, the Wond'rous Secret you diſcover;
A Lady ventures for a Friend,—a Lover.
Prodigious! For my part I frankly own,
I'd ſpoil'd the Wonder, and the Woman ſhown.
